HEADLINE: Spheres of Influence

BYLINE: By MARTIN JACQUES. 
Martin Jacques is the author of ''When China Rules the World: The End of the Western World and the Birth of a New Global Order.''

 BODY:
A CONTEST FOR SUPREMACY
China, America, and the Struggle for Mastery in Asia
By Aaron L. Friedberg
360 pp. W. W. Norton & Company. $27.95.
It seems inevitable that Chinese-/American relations will increasingly come to preoccupy the world. The United States continues to be the only global superpower, but in the not-too-distant future China promises to acquire the status of an equal or near equal. How this relationship evolves during a period when the balance of power between them is shifting so rapidly is inevitably a cause for concern.
To be sure, there is at least one important source of encouragement. Ever since the Nixon-Mao rapprochement in the 1970s, the relationship between the two countries has been remarkably stable, notwithstanding the many changes of leadership and the numerous twists and turns of history. The future, though, promises to be different. 
In ''A Contest for Supremacy,'' Aaron L. Friedberg outlines several reasons a closer relationship between the two powers is possible: economic interdependence, the prospect that China may become more open and democratic, its continuing integration into the international system, common threats like climate change, and nuclear weapons. Nonetheless, he believes two other factors -- a growing clash of interests and deep ideological and political differences -- will prove more decisive and will make the relationship more tense and competitive.
For Friedberg, a professor of politics and international affairs at Princeton, the stakes could hardly be greater. He quotes Lee Kuan Yew, the former prime minister of Singapore: ''If you do not hold your ground in the Pacific, you cannot be a world leader.'' Signaling his agreement, Friedberg writes: ''If we permit an illiberal China to displace us as the preponderant player in this most vital region, we will face grave dangers to our interests and our values throughout the world.'' Asia, as he correctly observes, is the key crucible of future conflict, with East Asia in particular set to assume central importance. This, after all, is China's backyard. It is already the most important economic region in the world.
Friedberg is certainly right that a situation characterized by the emergence of a rising power and the decline of an existing hegemon has generally been a recipe for instability and conflict. But the fact that the United States is a liberal democracy and China a one-party system is not as important as another factor Friedberg barely mentions: the very different histories and cultures of the two countries about which, in contrast, Henry Kissinger is eloquent in his recent book, ''On China.'' Friedberg's discussion is conducted largely, though not exclusively, in security terms, but by far the most important factor in determining the future will be economics. It is China's extraordinary economic performance that has been driving and will continue to drive the change in the relationship.
Friedberg's failure to give sufficient weight to that performance means that he underestimates the forces that, with enormous speed, are reshaping East Asia in China's favor and to America's disadvantage. Within a remarkably short space of time, China has become the largest market for most countries in East Asia, Japan included, and the destination for almost one-quarter of Asia's total exports, excluding India. The relative importance of the American market, on the other hand, is declining rapidly. China is fast becoming a major source of capital for many countries, while Beijing's decision to begin internationalizing the renminbi means that within the next five years it could rival the dollar in the settlement of East Asian trade.
As Friedberg points out, countries in the region are, in varying degrees, wary of China's rise. But the predominant trend over the last decade has been for them to move closer to Beijing. This, of course, was the pattern over the many centuries of the tributary system, a situation now being resumed as China once more assumes its position as the major economic power in the region. China's neighbors will be increasingly disinclined to antagonize it, because they are fully aware that their economic futures are bound up far more with Beijing than with Washington.
Friedberg similarly gives insufficient weight to America's economic decline. True, he recognizes that the Western financial crisis has hurt America badly, while China has been relatively little touched. But the effect of the crisis has been even more profound than is generally understood: it has ushered in a new era defined by American decline and the beginnings of a Chinese economic world order. So it is essential that America set itself realistic targets with regard to China and not seek to deal with the world as it was, but rather how it will be.
This brings me to Friedberg's conclusion. For the most part, the tenor of the book is considered, balanced, informative and restrained, even somewhat tentative in tone. In the final chapter, however, he adopts a far more strident voice. He takes issue with what he describes as the ''Shanghai Coalition,'' those in the United States who advocate engagement with China rather than containment, accusing them of self-interest or worse, and he mounts a fierce case for developing new military systems for projecting American power, including ''long-endurance unmanned aerial vehicles, submerged or low-observable 'arsenal ships' loaded with precision weapons, long-range conventional ballistic missiles and perhaps a new intercontinental-range stealthy manned bomber.'' Combined with a more assertive approach to China, he calls for a new security framework in Asia that includes the United States -- now largely excluded from regional organizations -- and what he describes as a ''community of Asian democracies'' designed specifically to neutralize Chinese ambitions.
Essentially, Friedberg seeks to counter China's rise in its own region by the deployment of hard power. This will inevitably lead to a more tense and dangerous international environment, quite possibly a new cold war. It is also highly doubtful whether it can be successful.
America's problem, ultimately, is not military but economic, a point also made by Kissinger. If the Chinese economy, as projected by Goldman Sachs, overtakes the American economy by 2027, and is almost double the size by 2050, then hawkish responses to China's power are misplaced. Instead, two very different emphases are required. First, America must concentrate on economic regeneration, including huge expenditure on modernizing its infrastructure and education system. Second, it must come to terms with the fact that China's rise and America's decline are not simply a result of a failure of policy but are rather one of those great -- and highly infrequent -- historical shifts that governments can do relatively little to affect, let alone prevent.

LENGTH: 2037 words

HEADLINE: In Company Town, Cuts but No Layoffs

BYLINE: By ANDREW MARTIN

 BODY:
WARROAD, Minn.
THREE THINGS matter big in this flyspeck city just south of the Canadian border: hockey, walleye and Marvin.
Not necessarily in that order. Yes, Warroad, nicknamed ''Hockeytown, U.S.A.,'' has sent six of its sons to the N.H.L. And the walleye plucked from Lake of the Woods are served for breakfast, lunch and dinner down at the Lakeview Restaurant.
But Marvin -- as in, Marvin Windows and Doors -- is the commercial engine in these parts and has been since George G. Marvin arrived in 1904. So when times get tough at Marvin, as they are now, the 1,700 or so residents of Warroad hold their collective breath.
But in this season of economic unease, when neither Washington nor Wall Street seems to have the answers, the descendants of George Marvin are going against the grain. Unlike so many other companies, Marvin Windows has neither laid off workers nor reduced health insurance benefits. And, its executives vow, it won't. 
Marvin Windows might seem like a footnote in the nation's economic ledger. It employs roughly 4,300 people, about 2,000 of them here, and has annual sales somewhere from $500 million to $1 billion. But what this company is doing -- and, more to the point, what it is not doing -- is worth knowing.
Marvin Windows and Doors is a throwback to another era. For starters, it is a private company. No public stockholders are complaining that the latest numbers fell short, that the share price is down.
What's more, Marvin takes an old-fashioned, even paternal view of its role here in Warroad, where the Marvin family has run things for just about as long as anyone can remember. The company has cut employees' pay and reduced perks like tuition reimbursement and 401(k) matching. Employees haven't received profit-sharing checks in two years, nor have the 16 members of the Marvin family who work for the company.
But, unlike its top competitors, Marvin has refused to fire people.
Many here wonder if Marvin can hold out, particularly if, as many fear, the economy sinks into another recession. Company executives say they aren't panicking yet.
''Housing isn't in a recession. It's in a depression,'' says Susan Marvin, the company's president and a granddaughter of George Marvin. ''While it's challenging for our people right now, and not everybody understands all the reasons why, the alternatives are devastating. These people would have to pick up and leave.''
Some have, for places like the booming oil fields of North Dakota. Others are working two jobs to make ends meet.
THE change is palpable in Warroad. This is a place where Marvin employees get the first Monday of November off for ''Deer Monday,'' so they can go hunting. And where on the Fourth of July the company hands out two nickels to children in town, as George Marvin did during the Depression.
When the housing market collapsed and, with it, the market for windows and doors, competitors shuttered plants and cut work forces. But as a fourth generation of Marvins prepares to take over, the most obvious -- some would argue most effective -- option was off the table.
While Marvin's story might seem quaint, even naive, Ms. Marvin says the no-layoff policy is as much a business wager as an act of benevolence. She says she is confident that it will ultimately pay off. Already, she says, Marvin is gaining market share from weakened rivals.
Ms. Marvin acknowledges that her family's private company may have more leeway than public counterparts. It has forgone profits for two years to keep everyone employed, for instance. Nonetheless, Ms. Marvin suggests that corporate America could learn a thing or two from Marvin's approach and long-term outlook.
''You can't cut your way to prosperity. You can't grow if you are cutting your lifeblood -- and that's the skills and experience your work force delivers,'' she says, adding later: ''Today, I think, to a great a degree, I think things have gotten out of balance. We see Wall Street almost punish companies that take the long view.''
Several other window manufacturers are based in the upper Midwest. (The abundance of white pine and the proximity to the Mississippi River were two reasons companies located there). Andersen is outside of St. Paul. Pella is in Iowa. Several dozen smaller operations are scattered throughout the region.
Like Marvin, many of these companies are privately held, often by descendants of their founders. Among the four biggest manufacturers, only Marvin and Jeld-Wen of Oregon continue to be managed by family members. Marvin is the smallest of the four.
Not surprisingly, the fortunes of window manufacturers are tied closely to housing construction and have followed the same precipitous rise and fall. New housing starts began climbing in 2000 and peaked in 2005, at more than two million, as new subdivisions sprouted across the country, particularly in the South and West.
Marvin's chief executive, Jake Marvin, says his company's peak year for profitability was 2006, and it continued to perform well through 2008.
Then the financial crisis hit, and housing construction collapsed. In 2005, an estimated 34.1 million windows were shipped for new construction. This year, that figure is projected to be 11.9 million. Mr. Marvin says new housing used to account for 60 percent of his business. These days, it is closer to 25 percent.
Most manufacturers responded to the collapse by closing plants and laying off employees, so much that the industry work force is a third smaller than it was a few years back, says Michael O'Brien, the chief executive of the Window and Door Manufacturers Association, a trade group.
Making matters worse, some manufacturers were saddled with debt from acquisitions they made in the boom years. Others confronted formidable financial problems.
Jeld-Wen, for instance, has closed 21 facilities and reduced its work force by 25 percent in the last three years, according to Standard & Poor's. The company is still struggling to fix its finances.
Other companies have made more modest layoffs, and like Marvin, they are trying to gain market share during the industry shakeout.
Kathy Krafka Harkema, a spokeswoman for Pella, says her company closed two plants, one in Iowa and one in Arizona. The move resulted in just over 300 layoffs. But Pella, which has roughly 8,000 employees, has remained profitable during the downturn, she says.
Mr. O'Brien at the window and door association says consumers remain skittish.
''It's always, 'Next year it will turn around,' '' he says. ''It's a challenge. No one thought we'd be where we are today, having not pulled out of it.''
THE fortunes of Warroad and Marvin Windows, like those of Detroit and the Big Three automakers, are deeply intertwined. Back when this was a Chippewa village, the Sioux invaded by way of the Red and Roseau Rivers, a route that ended at the mouth of the Warroad River -- the ''war road'' in the town's name.
Today there are more Marvin employees in Warroad, about 2,000, than there are residents, 1,722. (The company's other employees are scattered at plants in North Dakota, Tennessee, Virginia and Oregon.) The company's factory sits on the western edge of town. The visitor center, which includes a company museum that holds a lock of George Marvin's hair, is nearby, as is company headquarters. The Marvin Home Center, a spacious hardware store, is closer to the town center.
Mayor Bob Marvin is the brother of Jake Marvin, the chief executive, and Susan Marvin, the president. The town library, the senior center, the indoor swimming pool at the high school -- all were financed by Marvin or the Marvin family. So was most of the 1,700-seat hockey arena. A Marvin scholarship fund provides college tuition for about 20 Warroad graduates each year.
''These are people we went to school with,'' Jake Marvin says. ''We go to church with them. We see them in the same restaurants. Indeed, a lot of us have married local girls and boys.''
He later added, ''We could be anywhere. But we are in Warroad.''
JAKE MARVIN, a stout 63-year-old with slicked back hair, wire-rimmed glasses and a deep, gravelly voice, says he never saw the economic collapse coming. But when it came, he says, it wasn't too difficult to decide what to do.
Marvin Windows has laid off employees only once, in the late 1960s, Mr. Marvin says. He had no appetite to do it again. His grandfather kept his eight employees through the Depression.
Jake Marvin could afford to make that decision. His company had no debt and had some money in the bank. Call it luck or shrewd planning, but while others splurged on acquisitions in good times, Marvin Windows stuck to its knitting and grew organically.
Nonetheless, given the severity of the financial crisis, it became clear that something had to give. Other than jobs and medical benefits, everything was on the table.
Salaries were cut by 5 percent. Hourly workers were pulled back to 32 hours a week. While 32-hour weeks weren't uncommon during slow winters, this time the hours were reduced indefinitely. Raises were suspended, too.
In addition, Marvin stopped paying tuition reimbursement and financing a program that brought professors to Warroad to teach classes. Employees could no longer cash in vacation days they didn't use. Pizza parties and award ceremonies were nixed.
Employees were encouraged to take unpaid leave, and many did. Through attrition, Marvin pared its work force back to about 4,300 from a peak of over 5,000.
''Every month, something came off the table,'' Mr. Marvin says. ''We wanted to find a point where we could operate indefinitely until the market turned around.''
MARVIN'S no-layoff announcement was cheered by employees, and in April 2009, Ms. Marvin and a Marvin employee were hailed as ''great Americans'' on national television. But much of that euphoria has worn off in the three difficult years since, as the reality of smaller paychecks has taken hold.
''Is 32 tough? Absolutely,'' says Travis Kelley, a 16-year Marvin plant employee who took a second job at a local supermarket, Doug's, to help pay the bills. The cut in hours was harder than it might seem because Marvin workers made so much in overtime. ''We were taking home some big checks,'' Mr. Kelley, 39, says.
Nonetheless, Mr. Kelly said he was grateful for the job and had come to realize that he might have been spending too much anyway. ''I sold off my toys -- snowmobile, a couple of guns,'' he says. ''Now when I am home, I am home.''
Another Marvin employee, Nathan Hoy, 30, is working a second job at the Warroad Municipal Liquor Store. His reduced hours have taken a toll. ''You drive less, drink less, go out less often,'' he says.
In Warroad's downtown, at Lake Street Floral and Gifts, Toby Larson says business is down 40 percent. He attributes the decline to the cuts at Marvin and the broader economic malaise.
''As far as the person who used to buy off the sidewalk or cooler, that doesn't happen any more,'' he says.
Over at Thomson Thrifty White Pharmacy, the owner, Dennis Thomson, says customers are still filling prescriptions and buying items ''they need to live.'' Sales of discretionary items at the front of the store have fallen off.
With little chance of a quick turnaround, some Marvin employees have quit to try their chances elsewhere. Mike Gamache, who worked for the company for 15 years, says he was treated well and earned a two-year college degree on Marvin's dime.
But he left about six months ago, along with three friends from Warroad, to work in the North Dakota oil fields. ''It got to the point where you start looking around. I didn't see where the economic prospects for the company were getting any better,'' he says. ''If someone offers you $6 an hour more and tons more overtime, can you blame a guy?''
The Marvins don't dispute Mr. Gamache's assessment. But they don't have second thoughts about their no-layoff stand either, at least not publicly. Layoffs, they say, would hurt everyone here.
''I've talked to other business people about it, and they have challenged it. They have challenged the wisdom of it,'' Susan Marvin says.
Asked how long Marvin can keep its promises, given the potential for another recession, Jake Marvin replies with a question of his own: ''How long does that second recession last?''

HEADLINE: Tchaikovsky, Dress Codes, And 3-D Opera

BYLINE: By JAMES R. OESTREICH

 BODY:
Dates and performers are subject to change.
SEPTEMBER
'ATYS' The season is off and running. And a thoroughbred put out to pasture after a few great years is back in the gate: William Christie's acclaimed presentation of Lully's opera ''Atys'' with Les Arts Florissants, seen at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1989 and 1992, a landmark in the modern early-music movement. Some of the old costumes and wigs were dispersed to museums as Mr. Christie went on to other triumphs. But one Brooklyn Academy patron, Ronald P. Stanton, couldn't put the experience behind him. Avid to see the production again and having the wherewithal to do something about it, he financed this revival -- which has already made its way around Europe and appeared at Versailles, where the opera had its premiere in 1676 -- to the tune of $3.1 million. Once again, Jean-Marie Villegier directs, and Mr. Christie conducts Les Arts Florissants. Anything Mr. Christie is involved with carries an almost ironclad guarantee of quality. But this promises to be something truly special, as the Academy acknowledges by presenting it to kick off celebrations of its 150th anniversary. Opens today. BAM Howard Gilman Opera House. 
NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC After a hectic September preseason -- live accompaniments to the film of Bernstein's ''West Side Story''; a Mahler ''Resurrection'' Symphony for Sept. 11 (on Sept. 10, actually, with performances to follow on Sept. 22, 24 and 27); an Andrea Bocelli blowout in Central Park; and Walton's music for Shakespeare's ''Henry V'' with narration by Christopher Plummer -- Alan Gilbert and the orchestra finally get around to starting their season officially. The soprano Deborah Voigt, fresh off her portrayal of Annie Oakley in ''Annie Get Your Gun'' at the Glimmerglass Festival, shifts moods drastically and repeatedly in ''Dich, teure Halle'' from Wagner's ''Tannhauser,'' ''Andromache's Farewell'' by Samuel Barber and the final scene from Strauss's ''Salome.'' Ms. Voigt will presumably remain offstage, or at least clothed, as the orchestra adds Strauss's ''Dance of the Seven Veils.'' The concert is to be broadcast in the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series on PBS; let's hope that the players appear a happier bunch than they did in the glum PBS close-ups of last year's opening concert. Wednesday. Avery Fisher Hall.
KRONOS QUARTET This group has long been recognized as much for its pioneering social and internationalist mission as for its music-making, so a program addressing the 10th anniversary of Sept. 11 comes as no surprise. ''Awakening,'' originally presented in San Francisco for the fifth anniversary in 2006 and described as a musical meditation, has its New York premiere here. Composers represented include Michael Gordon, Terry Riley and Osvaldo Golijov, and the Brooklyn Youth Chorus joins in arrangements of traditional songs of various cultures. Wednesday-Saturday. BAM Harvey Theater.
NATIONAL SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA In a gala concert with several agendas, the ensemble opens its season and celebrates its 80th anniversary and the 40th of the Kennedy Center. Joshua Bell plays Bruch's First Violin Concerto, Thomas Hampson sings selections from Copland's ''Old American Songs,'' and Christoph Eschenbach, in his second season as the orchestra's music director, conducts it all, including a couple of sure-fire crowd pleasers: Dvorak's concert overture ''Carnival'' and Ravel's ''Bolero.'' Sept. 25. Kennedy Center Concert Hall, Washington, (202) 467-4600 or (800) 444-1324, kennedy-center.org.
'ANNA BOLENA' The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko is the lovely face (and sometimes bosom) of the Metropolitan Opera season, undoubtedly showing on a poster near you, as Manon if not Anna Bolena. For starters, the company has given Ms. Netrebko not only a new production and an opening-night showcase but a Donizetti work never presented in the house. How well the role's vocal fancywork will suit her voice in the big house remains to be seen, but one way or the other, she instantly becomes a part of Met history. David McVicar directs a cast that also includes Ekaterina Gubanova, Stephen Costello and Ildar Abdrazakov. Marco Armiliato conducts. Sept. 26. Metropolitan Opera House.
CHAMBER MUSIC SOCIETY OF LINCOLN CENTER The society opens its 43rd season with ''Fireworks!,'' a program celebrating virtuosity in works by Mendelssohn, Brahms, Saint-Saens and others. The society's artistic directors, the cellist David Finckel and the pianist Wu Han, anchor the performances. Sept. 26. Alice Tully Hall.
AMERICAN CLASSICAL ORCHESTRA This period-instrument band, conducted by Thomas Crawford, moves into Alice Tully Hall to start (and end) its 27th season. The well-balanced opening program features the mezzo-soprano Jill Grove in Brahms's Alto Rhapsody and adds Haydn's Symphony No. 104 (''London'') and Schubert's incidental music for ''Rosamunde.'' Sept. 29. Alice Tully Hall.
SEATTLE SYMPHONY Ludovic Morlot, in one of his first subscription series as this orchestra's new music director, serves up a doozy of a program, opening with Stravinsky's epochal ''Sacre du Printemps'' and closing with a work that carried it to its logical, raucous conclusion, Varese's ''Ameriques.'' In between, Mr. Morlot whimsically eases the pressure with, of all things, Gershwin's perky ''American in Paris.'' Well, the honking car horns, at least, should fit right in with the churning chaos that surrounds them. Sept. 29, Oct. 1. Benaroya Hall, (206) 215-4747 or (866) 833-4747, seattlesymphony.org.
BOSTON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA In what was supposed to be the last season of his contract as the orchestra's music director, James Levine, by present plans, will not conduct it at all. After the March announcement of his resignation, forced by chronic back problems (for which he continues to have operations), he was scrubbed from the schedule before it was announced, though some of his trademark programming remains in place, including a continuing cycle of the symphonies of John Harbison. As for Mr. Levine's eventual replacement, the orchestra -- which had to canvas conductors and their agents repeatedly to fill his vacancies in recent seasons -- must have a pretty good idea of who is out there. But now it accelerates the search with a parade of conductors that presents, along with elderly and fledgling maestros, plausible candidates, including Riccardo Chailly, surprisingly in his Boston Symphony debut; Andris Nelsons, who evidently impressed others in his debut with the orchestra in March more than he impressed me; and Esa-Pekka Salonen. But the season opens in understated fashion, with Anne-Sophie Mutter playing and leading the five Mozart violin concertos over two nights. Ms. Mutter, for her part, has made it clear that she has no conducting ambitions beyond overseeing her own performances. Sept. 30-Oct. 1. Symphony Hall, Boston, (617) 266-1492, bso.org.
VICTORIA SACRED WORKS You would expect the quiet celebrations of the 400th birthday of Tomas Luis de Victoria that are scattered about in concerts and on disc. What you might not have expected is a 10-CD set of 93 works newly recorded, some for the first time. But here it is, from Michael Noone and the 10-year-old Ensemble Plus Ultra, a London-based group specializing in Spanish Renaissance liturgical music, on Deutsche Grammophon Archiv. A Deutsche Grammophon blurb describes Victoria as ''a towering composer whose works glow with the passion and vibrant tonal palette of El Greco,'' presumably the case these recordings are trying to make. September.
OCTOBER
'THE THREEPENNY OPERA' Robert Wilson directs the Weill-Brecht classic, performed in German by the Berliner Ensemble, descended from the company founded by Bertolt Brecht and his wife in 1949. Mr. Wilson, the Brooklyn Academy says, has drawn on ''the striking designs of German Expressionist cinema and the shattering, seductive world of Weimar-era cabaret.'' There is also talk of a geometric concept, presumably coupled with a certain angularity of gesture, unless Mr. Wilson has lost his spots. Oct. 4-8. BAM Howard Gilman Opera House.
CARNEGIE HALL It is a great boon to latter-day Carnegie Hall programmers and marketers that Tchaikovsky -- having conducted a work of his own at the hall's opening concert, in 1891 -- can forever be commemorated as a sort of founding father. The hall continues its celebration of the 120th anniversary of that opening (which occurred last May) with a citywide festival, Tchaikovsky in St. Petersburg. Along with music, ballet and exhibits, there will be talks and panel discussions focusing on New York at the turn of the 20th century. One of St. Petersburg's great orchestras, the Mariinsky, and its maestro, Valery Gergiev, are in residence for the occasion, and they open the season here with Tchaikovsky's Variations on a Rococo Theme, with the cellist Yo-Yo Ma as soloist, as well as Shostakovich's ''Festive Overture'' and Rimsky-Korsakov's ''Scheherazade.'' Oct. 5.
ALAN GILBERT Alan Gilbert the fiddler, that is, performing Bach's D minor Concerto for Two Violins with the New York Philharmonic and the violinist Frank Peter Zimmermann, the orchestra's artist in residence this season. With that bit of showmanship out of his system, Mr. Gilbert reverts to form, conducting the Philharmonic in Berg's Violin Concerto, with Mr. Zimmermann as soloist, and Brahms's Third Symphony. Oct. 5-7. Avery Fisher Hall.
MARIINSKY ORCHESTRA Carnegie is spending so much Tchaikovsky capital celebrating its 120th anniversary that you have to wonder what it has in mind for its 125th, seemingly a bigger deal. (Fear not; the planners are already at work.) Here Valery Gergiev conducts his St. Petersburg-based ensemble in all six Tchaikovsky symphonies, in each case pairing an overfamiliar later work with a less familiar earlier one. The opening juxtaposition of the ever fresh First Symphony (''Winter Dreams'') with the soul-weary Sixth (''Pathetique'') should be especially striking, even disconcerting. Oct. 6, 9-10. Carnegie Hall.
DANIIL TRIFONOV Valery Gergiev, who as the new chairman of the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow, scored points for lending greater transparency and presumably more probity to the judging process in June, comes with a grand prize winner in tow. This young pianist, who also won the Rubinstein International Master Piano Competition in Tel Aviv in May and drew acclaim for a New York recital in July, joins Mr. Gergiev and the Mariinsky Orchestra in -- what else? -- Tchaikovsky's First Piano Concerto. The orchestra also plays Shostakovich's First Symphony and three selections from Prokofiev's ''Romeo and Juliet.'' Oct. 11. Carnegie Hall.
RACHMANINOFF VESPERS Kent Tritle, the choral maestro who swallowed Manhattan, continues to direct Musica Sacra, which he conducts here, even as he becomes music director and organist at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. (He also directs the Oratorio Society of New York and is organist of the New York Philharmonic and director of choral activities at the Manhattan School of Music.) Presented by Carnegie Hall, Rachmaninoff's a cappella Vespers is shoehorned into its St. Petersburg series, otherwise devoted mostly to Tchaikovsky, and I would be the last to object to a high-level performance of this glorious work, however it comes about. But Carnegie could have done a greater service to Tchaikovsky by highlighting some of his great liturgical music, less well-known but scarcely less exquisite than Rachmaninoff's and more revelatory of another side to Tchaikovsky than any of the orchestral war horses opening the season. (Maybe Nikolai Kachanov and the Russian Chamber Chorus of New York, who have made a specialty of Tchaikovsky's sacred works, will perform some at their Oct. 22 Carnegie neighborhood concert on Staten Island.) Oct. 12. Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 405 West 59th Street,(212) 330-7684, musicasacrany.com.
JORDI AND FERRAN SAVALL Inveterate followers of early music have come to know and love not only the virtuoso violist da gamba Jordi Savall but also his family: especially his wife, Montserrat Figueras, a wide-ranging vocalist, and their daughter, Arianna Savall, a harpist and singer. But I, for one, have encountered their son, Ferran, a lutenist and singer, only once, when all four performed together at the Metropolitan Museum. To say that he more than held his own in this exalted company is to say a lot. In ''Folias and Variations: Music Dialogues From Orient and Occident,'' a program presented by the Morgan and the Boston Early Music Festival, Ferran Savall, singing and playing theorbo, joins his father in works from the 13th through 17th centuries by Tobias Hume, Marin Marais and others. Oct. 12. Morgan Library & Museum, 225 Madison Avenue, at 36th Street, (212) 685-0008, ext. 560, themorgan.org.
SPHINX VIRTUOSI The Sphinx Organization has been working hard and long, 15 years now, to help black and Latino musicians prepare themselves for professional careers in classical music. Many wonderful players have gained recognition through its competitions, and some of them make up this aptly named group, which performs annually at Carnegie (formerly as the Sphinx Chamber Orchestra). The continuing paucity of blacks in major American symphony orchestras shows how sorely the organization's efforts are needed and how much work it still has to do. But for tonight, just enjoy the music in the hands of young, gifted and committed performers. Oct. 12. Carnegie Hall.
'DON GIOVANNI' There will be plenty to attend to onstage in a new production of Mozart's opera by Michael Grandage. Mariusz Kwiecien takes the title role opposite the scene-stealing Luca Pisaroni as Leporello. But a newly heightened curiosity will also be directed to the pit, as Fabio Luisi, suddenly the principal conductor at the Met, replaces an ailing James Levine on the podium. Separate article by Anthony Tommasini. Opens Oct. 13. Metropolitan Opera House.
MET ORCHESTRA And no sooner has Fabio Luisi spelled James Levine at the start of the Metropolitan Opera's ''Don Giovanni'' run than he conducts Met forces in another guise. From a program closely tailored to Mr. Levine's proclivities, Mr. Luisi retains John Harbison's ''Closer to My Own Life,'' in its premiere performance (with texts by Alice Munro sung by Christine Rice), but jettisons Gershwin's ''American in Paris'' in favor of Strauss's ''Till Eulenspiegel.'' The rest is Mozart: the Piano Concerto No. 25, with Richard Goode as soloist, and the ''Zauberflote'' Overture. Oct. 16. Carnegie Hall.
PAUL LEWIS You may well know this insightful pianist's comprehensive survey of Beethoven, on disc if not from concerts. You may even have followed some of his unfolding Schubert explorations. If not, time's a-wastin', and here are a couple of chances to catch up, with Schubert both familiar (Impromptus, ''Wanderer'' Fantasy, the later A minor Sonata) and less familiar. Oct. 18, April 26. 92nd Street Y.
LONDON SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA Lincoln Center's Great Performers series has yet to plunge into the brightness of the White Light Festival, but the venerable maestro Colin Davis can hardly be said to remain in the dark as he plies a specialty in the music of Sibelius: the Violin Concerto, with Nikolai Znaider as soloist, and the Second Symphony. Oct. 19. Avery Fisher Hall.
YUJA WANG Fashionistas may vie with pianistas for the good seats when this gifted and attractive young Chinese pianist makes her New York recital debut. Ms. Wang seems bent on radically altering concert dress, to judge from reports of her recent appearance at Hollywood Bowl wearing what The Los Angeles Times called ''an orange, thigh-grazing, body-hugging dress atop sparkly gold strappy stiletto sandals.'' Well, Hollywood Bowl is one thing; Carnegie Hall may be another (let alone the Ladies' Morning Musical Club in Montreal, three days later). The program, should anyone be listening, offers works by Scriabin, Liszt's Sonata in B minor and Prokofiev's Sonata No. 6, and the performances are almost sure to be wonderful. So what does Ms. Wang wear for an encore? Oct. 20. Carnegie Hall.
AMERICAN SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA The seemingly indefatigable and ever voluble Leon Botstein, president of Bard College, music director of this ensemble and inveterate champion of thematic programming, adds to his workload this season with preconcert chats, ''Conductor's Notes Q&As,'' presented an hour before each program. The first concert, ''Bauhaus Bach,'' tracing connections between Bach and modernism, follows on the exhibition ''Lyonel Feininger: At the Edge of the World'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art and presents works of Bach orchestrated by Wolfgang Graeser, Reger and Schoenberg; Schoenberg's Variations for Orchestra; and Feininger's own composition Three Fugues. Oct. 21. Carnegie Hall.
WHITE LIGHT FESTIVAL ''It's such a great work, it should never be performed,'' Colin Davis has said of Beethoven's ''Missa Solemnis.'' Happily, he has not lived by that bit of hyperbole (reported by John Canarina in his book ''The New York Philharmonic: From Bernstein to Maazel,'' Amadeus Press, 2010), and Mr. Davis tries to take the measure of the work again, with the London Symphony Orchestra and Chorus, as the second annual White Light Festival at Lincoln Center gets rolling. Then Gianandrea Noseda leads the orchestra and chorus in another daunting masterpiece, Britten's ''War Requiem,'' with the tenor Ian Bostridge and the baritone Simon Keenlyside delivering the death-haunted poetry of Wilfred Owen. Oct. 21, 23. Avery Fisher Hall.
TENET This vocal group, directed by Jolle Greenleaf, stole the show in an early-music sampler program a year ago with a segment called ''A Feast for the Senses.'' One number in particular, Charles H. Gabriel's hymn ''His Eye Is on the Sparrow,'' with the line ''I sing because I'm happy,'' epitomized the group's approach to the whole: a sheer, unabashed joy in music-making. Here Tenet presents the program complete to celebrate release of its ''Feast for the Senses'' CD. Oct. 22. St. Ignatius of Antioch Episcopal Church, 552 West End Avenue, (646) 470-5809, tenetnyc.com.
PACIFICA QUARTET With Hilde Limondjian having left her position as director of concerts and lectures at the Metropolitan Museum more than a year ago, and her successor, Limor Tomer, having arrived only in May, this will be a season of transition in programming. Lisa Doyle, the senior manager of concerts and lectures, and the staff did most of the planning, and some old formulas now seem open to question. But this one remains strong: a series of Saturday evening concerts by a resident string quartet in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium. For more than four decades, it was the Guarneri Quartet; since 2009, it has been the Pacifica. Having dispatched the 15 Shostakovich quartets last season, the Pacifica now presents a complete cycle of Beethoven's 16 quartets. The first program sets the pattern, with works early (Op. 18, No. 2), middle (Op. 74) and late (Op. 131). Oct. 22 (also Nov. 12, Dec. 10, Jan. 7, Feb. 25, March 10). Metropolitan Museum.
JENNIFER KOH Two seasons ago, this fine violinist played Bach's unaccompanied sonatas and partitas one per day in a popular series of free lunchtime concerts presented by the Miller Theater in Philosophy Hall of Columbia University. Now she puts all six works together in a single afternoon in the theater itself. To judge from reports on the earlier performances, tickets will probably be scarce. Oct. 23. Miller Theater, 2960 Broadway, at 116th Street, (212) 854-7799, millertheatre.com.
ANNA NETREBKO The Russian diva is almost as ubiquitous as Tchaikovsky this season, and -- no surprise -- she sings 8 of his songs here, in her New York recital debut, alongside 11 by Rimsky-Korsakov. Elena Bashkirova is the pianist. Oct. 26. Carnegie Hall.
'SIEGFRIED' What can Robert Lepage possibly add to the technological wonders of the first two installments of his unfolding Wagner ''Ring'' cycle at the Met? Why, the latest wrinkle, of course: 3-D. ''If the technology works as advertised, the singers will appear to move inside a three-dimensional world created by projections,'' Daniel J. Wakin and Steve Lohr reported in The New York Times. ''But tuxedo-clad operagoers will not face the indignity of wearing goofy 3-D glasses.'' Amazing, to be sure, but none of this helps -- you have to hope that it doesn't hinder -- the poor tenor at center stage for most of five hours, singing his heart and his voice out: in this case, Gary Lehman, replacing Ben Heppner, who withdrew from the punishing role in February because, according to his manager, it ''was just not the right repertoire for him.'' The opera is also a long haul for the conductor, and here again, Fabio Luisi has replaced James Levine. Deborah Voigt sings Brunnhilde; Bryn Terfel, the Wanderer; Eric Owens, Alberich. Opens Oct. 27. Metropolitan Opera House.
MINNESOTA ORCHESTRA As much as we love hearing Osmo Vanska and these players perform symphonies of Sibelius and Beethoven (and we do), it is high time New Yorkers got to hear something else from them, and here it is. As the Tchaikovsky binge continues, the probing pianist Stephen Hough can be counted on to provide fresh insights into the First Concerto, and perhaps Mr. Vanska can awaken interest in the ''Voyevoda'' Overture. But the real attraction is the ''Sinfonia Espansiva,'' the Third Symphony of the great Dane Carl Nielsen, whose works are not heard here nearly enough (though Alan Gilbert has also taken up the cause at the New York Philharmonic, which will perform the ''Espansiva,'' in June). Mr. Vanska and his quasi-Scandinavian band should be just the ones to do the music justice. Oct. 27. Carnegie Hall.
BUDAPEST FESTIVAL ORCHESTRA The thoughtful Hungarian-born pianist Andras Schiff begins his season-long Carnegie Perspectives series, focusing on Bartok, with favorite collaborators: the conductor Ivan Fischer and the Budapest players, who are becoming regular and welcome visitors to New York. Mr. Schiff performs the three Bartok piano concertos over two evenings. Mr. Fischer and the orchestra fill out the programs with works of Schubert, including the Fifth and Ninth Symphonies, and more Bartok. Separate article by Vivien Schweitzer. Oct. 28-29. Carnegie Hall.
MIDORI This excellent violinist, possessed of a rare aesthetic and social sensibility, has carved out a major career on her own terms, devoting at least as much effort to education and public service as to performing. After her repertory adventures and commissioning projects of recent years, she reverts to standard fare -- works of Mozart, Schubert, Schumann and Shostakovich -- for this recital, and she should be at her communicative best in the Y's intimate hall. Ozgur Aydin is the pianist. Oct. 29. 92nd Street Y.
JONAS KAUFMANN The way cancellations have gone in recent seasons, the Met should post betting odds with its rosters. This German tenor, who has swept all before him in recent seasons at the house, is scheduled to make his New York recital debut there less than two months, it turns out, after surgery to remove a node from his chest. Helmut Deutsch is the pianist. So what are the odds? Oct. 30. Metropolitan Opera House.
ANDRAS SCHIFF AT CARNEGIE The pianist Mr. Schiff rounds out the opening volley of his Perspectives concerts with a recital in the Stern Auditorium, offering more Bartok, the Piano Sonata, along with Bach's Three-Part Inventions and Beethoven's ''Diabelli'' Variations. Separate article by Vivien Schweitzer. Oct. 31. Carnegie Hall.
IVES VIOLIN SONATAS Hilary Hahn is the latest in a line of superb active female violinists with a fiercely independent streak, not following in the footsteps of Anne-Sophie Mutter, Midori or anyone else. It is only appropriate that Ms. Hahn should alight on the music of the surly nonconformist Charles Ives. Valentina Lisitsa is the equally fine pianist on this Deutsche Grammophon release, which should do much to establish these four works in the active repertory. October.
NOVEMBER
ROBERT ASHLEY A big season for the composer Robert Ashley begins with several nights of old and new pieces performed by his associates Tom Hamilton and Thomas Buckner with a number of young players, followed by a guerrilla performance of his opera ''Perfect Lives'' by the experimental ensemble thingNY in private and public spaces on the Lower East Side. Separate article by Steve Smith. Nov. 1, 4-5. St. Mark's Church in the Bowery, 131 East 10th Street, (212) 420-1916, incubatorarts.org. Nov. 6. Various locations.
'KOYAANISQATSI' Though no expert on film, admittedly, I found this effort by Godfrey Reggio hopelessly simplistic in its lamentation of the ''life out of balance'' of the subtitle, despite its gorgeous cinematography. Some might level a similar charge against Philip Glass's music, but for me it was the best part of the film: enough to elevate it above the ordinary. The New York Philharmonic and the Philip Glass Ensemble play the score live to accompany a screening of the film, with Michael Riesman conducting. Separate article by Allan Kozinn. Nov. 2-3. Avery Fisher Hall.
'SPECTRAL SCRIABIN' Not all the light in Lincoln Center's White Light Festival is a transcendent white. In this production, for a program of Scriabin played by the Georgian pianist Eteri Andjaparidze, the lighting designer Jennifer Tipton updates the various experiments with color organs extending back at least to the 18th century and expands on Scriabin's own cues for colorization in his orchestral ''Promethee: La Poeme du Feu.'' Nov. 3-5. Baryshnikov Arts Center, 450 West 37th Street, (212) 721-6500, whitelightfestival.org.
PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA As its financial doldrums drag on and key players decamp or contemplate new positions, the orchestra waits yet another season for its new music director, Yannick Nezet-Seguin, to arrive. The stalwart Charles Dutoit continues in the interim position of chief conductor, and in a significant gesture, Mr. Nezet-Seguin has added a fourth week of subscription concerts to the three he was scheduled to conduct this season. But the dispirited ensemble needs more than gestures, and you have to wonder how long the center can hold. For his first subscription week, Mr. Nezet-Seguin offers Mozart's Symphony No. 40 and -- with the soprano Dorothea Roschmann, the baritone Matthias Goerne and the Westminster Symphonic Choir -- Brahms's ''German Requiem.'' Nov. 3-5. Kimmel Center for the Performing Arts, (215) 893-1999, philorch.org.
'SATYAGRAHA' Richard Croft returns as Gandhi in a revival of Phelim McDermott's production of this touchstone work by Philip Glass. Separate article by Allan Kozinn. Opens Nov. 4. Metropolitan Opera House.
ATLANTA SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA The orchestra missed a chance to play in Carnegie Hall in May, when it had to cancel its participation in the Spring for Music Festival for financial reasons. But here it appears under Carnegie's own auspices, with its music director, Robert Spano, conducting Scriabin's ''Poem of Ecstasy''; Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3, with Garrick Ohlsson as a presumably commanding soloist; and the New York premiere of Esa-Pekka Salonen's ''Nyx.'' If there is a New York connection embedded in the title of that work, commissioned by Carnegie Hall, Mr. Salonen's Web site (esapekkasalonen.co.uk) guards the secret well. Nov. 5. Carnegie Hall.
OPERA ORCHESTRA OF NEW YORK In his first concert as the company's full-fledged music director, Alberto Veronesi conducts Cilea's ''Adriana Lecouvreur.'' The ''dream cast,'' as the company's Web site (operaorchestrany.org) calls it (wait, aren't the newly enriched Philadelphia Eagles the dream team?), is led by Angela Gheorghiu and Jonas Kaufmann: a sort of consolation prize for the Gheorghiu-Kaufmann partnership that won't be happening in the Met's ''Faust,'' even if Mr. Kaufmann has recovered from his preseason surgery by then, because of Ms. Gheorghiu's withdrawal. Nov. 8. Carnegie Hall.
'DARK SISTERS' As New York awaits a Nico Muhly opera on a large scale -- ''Two Boys,'' which opened to considerable acclaim at the English National Opera in June and is due at the Metropolitan in the 2013-14 season -- the Gotham Chamber Opera presents the premiere of one on a small scale. Set to a libretto by Stephen Karam and based in part on reports out of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, it deals with the plight of a woman trapped in a polygamous relationship and those of her sister wives. Opens Nov. 9. Gerald W. Lynch Theater, John Jay College, 899 10th Avenue, at 58th Street, (212) 279-4200, gothamchamberopera.org.
OLIVIER LATRY This French virtuoso played all the organ works of the great mystic Olivier Messiaen on the Mander organ at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in six programs in 2000. You might think that this single concert of Messiaen, part of Lincoln Center's White Light Festival, represented a mere distillation, but nothing about Messiaen is mere. Spiritual exaltation is assured, and this should be a good technical workout for the reinstalled and restored Kuhn organ, showing the range of its distinctively French colorations. Nov. 11. Alice Tully Hall.
HUELGAS ENSEMBLE The White Light Festival at Lincoln Center seems to have adapted Thomas Tallis's 40-part motet, ''Spem in Alium,'' as a sort of theme song. Last year the festival, in its first season, presented an installation based on the work: an electronic deconstruction that placed listeners inside a circle of 40 speakers, each delivering mainly the sound of a single voice. Now this excellent Belgian choir, directed by Paul Van Nevel, performs the work straight, in the first of two festival concerts in more or less neighboring churches. That program, ''Utopia,'' also offers works by Gabrieli, Striggio, Brumel, Josquin and others. The second program, ''Medieval Apocalypse,'' includes works by Perotin, Machaut, Ciconia and Matteo de Perugia. Nov. 10. Fourth Universalist Church, 160 Central Park West. Nov. 12. Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 146 West 46th Street, (212) 721-6500, whitelightfestival.org.
VIENNA SYMPHONY No question, this is Vienna's other orchestra, though still in a very good league. Unlike the Vienna Philharmonic, it has a principal conductor, Fabio Luisi, whom New York is quickly getting to know as an opera maestro, now the principal conductor of the Metropolitan Opera and the presumptive heir to James Levine as music director. But the Vienna orchestras have things in common beyond their home city: for one, of the 25 or so Vienna Symphony players pictured in Lincoln Center's brochure, 2, maybe 3, are women, and fuller pictures on the orchestra's Web site (wiener-symphoniker.at) show an even smaller percentage of women. In two programs, Mr. Luisi conducts works by Beethoven (Triple Concerto), Brahms (Second Symphony), that Austrian favorite Franz Schmidt (Fourth Symphony) and Rachmaninoff (Second Piano Concerto, with Lisa de la Salle as soloist). Nov. 13-14. Avery Fisher Hall.
ORCHESTRE REVOLUTIONNAIRE ET ROMANTIQUE John Eliot Gardiner and his period band have visited New York in recent years with substantial helpings of Haydn and Mozart. Could Beethoven have been far behind? Here they offer most of the heart of Beethoven's batting order, the Symphonies Nos. 3, 4, 5 and 7, along with the overtures to ''Egmont'' and ''The Creatures of Prometheus.'' Nov. 16-17. Carnegie Hall.
'KOMMILITONEN!' British eyebrows twitched when the Scottish composer Peter Maxwell Davies, a former enfant terrible, was appointed master of the queen's music in 2004. Did the queen (or whoever dispenses such honors) know what she was getting? Had Sir Peter gone soft in his knighthood (conferred in 1987)? Not entirely, it seems. ''My new opera deals with brave students who stood up for what they believed in and triggers a wonderful example of adversity,'' Mr. Davies has said of ''Kommilitonen (Young Blood!),'' which had its premiere in March at the Royal Academy of Music in London. The opera interweaves three stories of students embroiled in political activity, in Germany, China and the United States. ''At the end,'' Mr. Davies says, ''everything comes together in a great cry of freedom.'' Anne Manson conducts the Juilliard Orchestra and Juilliard Opera singers in the American premiere of the work, commissioned by the Juilliard School and the British academy. David Pountney, the librettist, directs. Nov. 16, 18, 20. Peter Jay Sharp Theater, Juilliard School.
EUGENE SYMPHONY Spring for Music, a festival intended to encourage adventurous symphonic programming, made its debut in May at Carnegie Hall, drawing welcome attention to the full range of North American orchestras, including smaller ones not often heard outside their home regions. Perhaps the greatest triumph was the Oregon Symphony's, with an imaginative program built on a war theme. But Oregon evidently has another orchestra capable of thinking big thoughts. The Eugene Symphony opens Counterpoint 2011, a three-week series of concerts and community events centering on the topic of war and peace, with a performance of Shostakovich's ''Leningrad'' Symphony, conducted by its music director, Danail Rachev. Other concerts will include John Adams's ''On the Transmigration of Souls,'' a Sept. 11 commemoration, and Copland's ''Lincoln Portrait,'' in a multimedia presentation narrated by Tom Brokaw (Nov. 22); and Beethoven's ''Eroica'' Symphony (Dec. 1). Nov. 17. Hult Center, Eugene, Ore., (541) 682-5000, eugenesymphony.org.
TAFELMUSIK BAROQUE ORCHESTRA This respected ensemble has devised ambitious thematic programs in recent years: notably, ''The Galileo Project,'' a riveting theatrical evening experienced at Tafelmusik's home base in Toronto in March. We can hope that one of those programs will find its way to New York soon, but the looser assemblage of works by Lully, Bach, Fasch and Vivaldi here should serve handsomely in the meantime. Nov. 18. Zankel Hall.
BALTIMORE SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA Not to trivialize the exploits and martyrdom of Joan of Arc, but Marin Alsop, this ensemble's music director, knows a thing or two about overcoming obstacles in a field dominated by men. So who can blame her if, as she conducts Honegger's oratorio ''Jeanne d'Arc au Bucher,'' she identifies just a touch with the heroine? An array of choruses includes the Concert Artists of Baltimore, the Peabody-Hopkins Chorus and the Morgan State University Choir. Nov. 19. Carnegie Hall.
'THAT MORNING THING' Robert Ashley's 1967 opera receives a new production as part of the Performa 11 series. Separate article by Steve Smith. Nov. 19-21. The Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, (212) 255-5793, thekitchen.org.
ORPHEUS CHAMBER ORCHESTRA The conductorless ensemble, pushing 40 and comfortably ensconced in an annual series at Carnegie Hall, has plenty of laurels to rest on. But it looks to fresh adventures this season, taking on its first composer in residence, Gabriel Kahane, and starting a new series at Galapagos in Brooklyn. The first concert there presents two segments by Mr. Kahane -- his ''Orinoco Sketches,'' based on the diary of a grandmother who fled Nazi Germany, and songs from his new album, ''Where Are the Arms'' -- alongside Hindemith's Kammermusik No. 1 (which will also be heard at Carnegie on Dec. 3). Mr. Kahane supplies vocals and plays piano. Nov. 20. Galapagos Art Space, 16 Main Street, Dumbo, Brooklyn, (718) 222-8500, galapagosartspace.com.
'FAUST' Again, you have to make allowances for the pace of Jonas Kaufmann's recovery from surgery in September. Mr. Kaufmann is scheduled to take the title role here as -- in Des McAnuff's production, shared with the English National Opera -- an aging nuclear physicist in the aftermath of Hiroshima. (Other Fausts, Roberto Alagna and Joseph Calleja, are to appear later in the run in any case.) Marina Poplavskaya replaces the originally announced Angela Gheorghiu as Marguerite, and Rene Pape is a Mephistopheles not likely to be lost in the shadows. Yannick Nezet-Seguin conducts. Opens Nov. 29. Metropolitan Opera House.
BACH TRAUERMUSIK With the Taverner Consort and Players, the conductor and scholar Andrew Parrott presents his reconstruction of Bach's funeral music for Prince Leopold, his former patron at Cothen, first performed by the New York Collegium in 2004. Do not expect something completely new and different. Writing in 1728, Bach evidently drew heavily on the near-contemporaneous ''St. Matthew Passion,'' so most of the tunes -- and what tunes! -- will be familiar, but the texts will not. A fascinating venture. Avie Records. November.
DECEMBER
'ORANGO' The opera 'Lady Macbeth of the Mtsensk District' got Shostakovich into a heap of trouble with Soviet officialdom after its premiere in 1934; he didn't need more. So it may be just as well that he never finished ''Orango,'' a satirical opera (involving a hybrid of human and ape) aimed at the press, which he worked on at the same time. He completed only the prologue, 40 minutes of music, in a piano-vocal score discovered in 2006, which the musicologist Gerard McBurney has orchestrated. Esa-Pekka Salonen conducts the Los Angeles Philharmonic and the Los Angeles Master Chorale in the premiere of that version, with staging directed by Peter Sellars. Mr. Salonen also conducts the orchestra in Shostakovich's Fourth Symphony, and the political history of that work is a whole other story. Dec. 2-4. Walt Disney Concert Hall, Los Angeles, (323) 850-2000, laphil.com.
PITTSBURGH SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA There have been staged productions of Handel's ''Messiah'': notably, in recent decades, those of Achim Freyer in Berlin and Deborah Warner in London, but they were conceived for opera companies. At a time when symphony orchestras have been all too ready to cede Baroque repertory to early-music specialists, the Pittsburgh Symphony seems an unlikely source for this sort of experimentation. But there it is: a fully staged production, it is said, ''with dramatic lighting effects, costumes and sets, with the orchestra in the pit.'' Where the Mendelssohn Choir of Pittsburgh will find a perch is anyone's guess. The orchestra's innovative music director, Manfred Honeck, will conduct, and Sam Helfrich will direct. Dec. 2-4. Heinz Hall, (412) 392-4900 or (800) 743-8560, pittsburghsymphony.org.
'MESSIAH' There is no lack of excellent performances of Handel's seasonal oratorio at Christmastime (no matter that this is not the season Handel wrote for) in New York. Kent Tritle alone will conduct two different versions on three consecutive days at Carnegie Hall (Dec. 19, the Mozart arrangement with the Oratorio Society of New York; Dec. 20 and 21, straight Handel with Musica Sacra), both eminently recommendable. But the St. Thomas Choir of Men and Boys, trained and conducted by John Scott, is generally first off the mark and often stands up as the best in the end. As always, the orchestra is the fine period-instrument Concert Royal. Dec. 6, 8. St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue at 53rd Street, (212) 757-7013, saintthomaschurch.org.
LONDON PHILHARMONIC ORCHESTRA When the Philadelphia Orchestra was looking for its next music director, Vladimir Jurowski -- the London Philharmonic's principal conductor, who had had great success in Philadelphia -- met with a groundswell of support. But once the Philadelphia administrators had settled on Yannick Nezet-Seguin, you began to hear less of Mr. Jurowski in this country. You would like to think that these concerts might rekindle interest, but Tchaikovsky's ''Manfred'' comes like coals to Newcastle at Carnegie this season, and not the highest-grade coals at that. And the two programs are otherwise of interest as much for their soloists -- Janine Jansen in Mozart's Violin Concerto No. 5, Emanuel Ax in Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 5 -- as for Mr. Jurowski's moments in the spotlight: Matthias Pintscher's ''towards Osiris'' and Brahms's Fourth Symphony. Dec. 7-8. Carnegie Hall.
ELLIOTT CARTER The birthdays keep coming, and so do the compositions. The cellist Fred Sherry is organizing a concert for Mr. Carter's 103rd birthday that will include the premiere of a string trio and the American premieres of a double trio and a work called ''Trije Glasbeniki'' (''Three Musicians,'' in Slovenian). And who knows? Maybe Mr. Carter will have dashed off another piece or three for the occasion. Dec. 8. 92nd Street Y. TRINITY CHOIR And yet another run of ''Messiah'' performances. The Trinity Choir and its attendant orchestras, in their many activities for the Sept. 11 anniversary, gave considerable evidence that under Julian Wachner's directorship, they are very near the top of musical life in New York, and you can expect further proof here. Yes, I know, music may be incidental to their higher purpose, but they sure know how to pull music lovers into a church that for most of them is well out of the way. Dec. 11, 12. Trinity Church, Broadway at Wall Street, (212) 602-0800, trinitywallstreet.org. Dec. 19. Alice Tully Hall.
ANONYMOUS 4 This wonderful female vocal quartet is celebrating a 25th anniversary. But wait: how does the Great Disbandment of Aught-Four figure into that? Aw, who cares. Just be grateful that the group is still around to take part in the Met Museum's cherished holiday series with music appropriate to the season performed before the Christmas tree and Neapolitan Baroque creche in the Medieval Sculpture Hall. Dec. 15. Metropolitan Museum.
CONTACT! O.K., so maybe things are changing, incrementally, at the New York Philharmonic. The orchestra continues to ghettoize contemporary music in this series of concerts off premises, but it celebrates Beethoven's birthday in the quirkiest fashion imaginable (though not the most contemporary), with H. K. Gruber singing his 1977 magnum opus, ''Frankenstein!!'' Alan Gilbert conducts a program that also includes Magnus Lindberg's ''Gran Duo'' and Alexandre Lunsqui's ''Fibers, Yarn and Fabric.'' Dec. 16. Metropolitan Museum. Dec. 17. Symphony Space.
'THE ENCHANTED ISLAND' For the man who has every role: this pastiche -- cobbled together in good Baroque fashion from music of Handel, Vivaldi, Rameau and others by Jeremy Sams, who supplies his own English libretto -- gives Placido Domingo a way to expand his seemingly limitless repertory without having to resort to more baritone roles or conductorial gigs. He sings Neptune in a loose revamp of Shakespeare's ''Tempest'' and ''Midsummer Nights' Dream.'' Joyce DiDonato is Sycorax; Danielle de Niese, Ariel; David Daniels, Prospero. William Christie conducts, and Phelim McDermott directs. This confection may be just frothy enough for New Year's Eve. How it will stand up on long, cold, punishing nights in January and February remains to be seen. Opens Dec. 31. Metropolitan Opera House.

GREEN MOUNTAIN PROJECTPerformances of Monteverdi's 1610 Vespers by this group, built around Jolle Greenleaf's vocal ensemble Tenet, at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin were highlights of the New York season for two Januarys running. Now, evidently trusting that the third outing will be an even greater charm, the project is relocating and expanding, with a second performance in New York and a third in Cambridge, Mass. It is also deepening its explorations, this time presenting what it calls ''Vespers of 1640,'' combining music from Monteverdi's ''Selva Morale e Spirituale'' with works of Giovanni Gabrieli. Jan. 3-4. Church of St. Jean Baptiste, 184 East 76th Street. Jan. 7. St. Paul's Church, Cambridge, (646) 470-5809, tenetnyc.com.
MAHLER PROJECT Gustavo Dudamel conducts all the Mahler symphonies in just over three weeks: Nos. 1, 4, 6, 9 and 10 (Adagio) with the Los Angeles Philharmonic; Nos. 2, 3, 5 and 7 with the Simon Bolivar Symphony Orchestra (formerly Simon Bolivar Youth Orchestra) of Venezuela; No. 8 (''Symphony of a Thousand'') with both orchestras. For good measure, in the first program -- alongside the Fourth Symphony, with the soprano Miah Persson as soloist -- Mr. Dudamel throws in the ''Lieder Eines Fahrenden Gesellen,'' sung by Thomas Hampson. Then, with all that behind them, the Los Angeles players will follow Mr. Dudamel and the Venezuelans to Caracas, where they will perform the symphony cycle again in mid-February. Jan. 13-15 (also Jan. 19-21, 22, 24, 26-29, 31; Feb. 2-5). Walt Disney Concert Hall, Shrine Auditorium (No. 8), Los Angeles, (323) 850-2000, laphil.com.
MUSIC OF TEREZIN Will to Create, Will to Live is an interdisciplinary series of concerts, films, exhibits and lectures focusing on artists who, in the Y's description, ''during World War II faced the horrors of incarceration and death yet managed to persevere and raise their voices.'' The Nash Ensemble of Britain presents three programs, sharing two of them with the baritone Wolfgang Holzmair and the pianist Russell Ryan. THOMAS HAMPSON Much of the Met Museum's concert programming this season is tied to exhibitions or openings of galleries. In this case, to greet the New American Wing Galleries for Paintings, Sculpture and Decorative Arts, which opens on Jan. 16, the estimable baritone Mr. Hampson continues his multiyear project ''Song of America,'' performing works of Copland, Barber, Ives, Thomson and others in the American Wing, with Craig Rutenberg as pianist. Jan. 22. Metropolitan Museum.
OPERA LAYAYETTE It has always seemed odd that -- as the season-opening ''Atys'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music reminds us -- God's greatest gift to French Baroque opera in the modern era should have been an American, the conductor William Christie. It seems hardly less surprising that Mr. Christie's work should be notably furthered by another American, Ryan Brown, and his Washington-based company. They visited New York in February with ''Le Magnifique'' by Gretry, a composer some had heard on recordings if not encountered live. But Monsigny? You're more likely to know the street in Paris than Pierre-Alexandre Monsigny, the composer of ''Le Roi et le Fermier,'' a 1762 gloss on social issues that Opera Lafayette brings to New York between its opening at the Kennedy Center in Washington (Jan. 21) and two performances at Versailles. Didier Rousselet is the director, and Mr. Brown conducts a cast including Dominique Labelle, Yulia Van Doren and William Sharp. Jan. 26. Frederick P. Rose Theater, 60th Street and Broadway, (202) 546-9332, operalafayette.org.
'GOTTERDAMMERUNG' And now that Robert Lepage has constructed his wondrous technological contraption of a Wagner ''Ring'' cycle, it is time for it all to come crashing down. Even in lower-tech productions, the final conflagration has occasionally produced moments of actual physical danger for some on stage. (Hildegard Behrens was decked by a stray beam at the Met in 1990.) Enough has already gone wrong with the current mechanisms, and enough pratfalls have occurred on the monstrous set, that a shiver of real fear may accompany the illusion of Valhalla's collapse. This will also be the time to check in on James Levine's recovery, since he now projects these performances as his return to the podium. Opens Jan. 27. Metropolitan Opera House.
FOCUS! FESTIVAL On one hand, this contemporary-music event's focus is narrower than usual, since it centers on a single composer, John Cage, in honor of his centenary. On the other hand, Cage was in some ways the least focused of composers, ranging restlessly through musical styles and the sounds of silence, and venturing into the worlds of literature, dance and visual art. The festival will touch mostly on the musical manifestations and will touch on other American composers in performances by the New Juilliard Ensemble and the Juilliard Percussion Ensemble. Jan. 27-Feb. 3. Peter Jay Sharp Theater, Paul Hall, Juilliard School; Alice Tully Hall.
KAYHAN KALHOR Here is another concert at the Met Museum inspired by a new display space, in this case the New Galleries for the Art of the Arab Lands, Turkey, Iran, Central Asia and Later South Asia, which opens on Nov. 1. No one familiar with the Iranian Mr. Kalhor's emotionally rich yet superbly nuanced playing of the kamancheh (a Persian spike fiddle) -- and many Westerners are familiar with it, thanks especially to Yo-Yo Ma's Silk Road Project -- will want to miss this evening of traditional Persian music. (Mr. Kalhor's latest recording, ''I Will Not Stand Alone,'' is to be released by World Village in connection with the concert.) Jan. 28. Metropolitan Museum.
'RIENZI' When Eve Queler gave up the music directorship of the Opera Orchestra of New York in the spring, she left some business unfinished. In the 2008-9 season, the company, hit hard by the recession, had to cancel a concert performance of this early Wagner opera, which it had made something of a specialty over the decades. It promised the work for the next season but is only now catching up. Ms. Queler, as music director laureate, conducts the New York Choral Society and a cast including Ian Storey and Elisabete Matos. Jan. 29. Avery Fisher Hall.
AMERICAN COMPOSERS ORCHESTRA With ''Koyaanisqatsi'' and ''Satyagraha'' already out of the way, there continues to be a lot of music by Philip Glass this season, much of it in connection with his 75th birthday. The performance here, the American premiere of his Ninth Symphony, hits the birthday right on the nose. Dennis Russell Davies, a longtime Glass champion, conducts a program that also includes the New York premiere of Arvo Part's ''Lamentate.'' Separate article by Allan Kozinn. Jan. 31. Carnegie Hall.

COLLEGIATE CHORALE ''A Child of Our Time,'' by Michael Tippett, and Bruckner's Te Deum, each a compelling choral statement in its own right, otherwise have little in common, but that's what intermissions are for. MET + JUILLIARD Two years ago in this space, through a slip of the brain, I attributed the ''Armida'' being presented by the Metropolitan Opera to Gluck rather than Rossini. Now I can properly welcome Gluck's ''Armide,'' which in fact was performed in concert in that 2009-10 season, by Opera Lafayette, and which Anthony Tommasini called ''a seemingly flawless masterpiece'' in The New York Times It will be jointly presented here by the Met and the Juilliard School in a semistaging directed by Fabrizio Melano. IMMORTAL INVESTMENTS The good thing about a festival devoted to, say, Tchaikovsky or Oswald von Wolkenstein, is that you have a pretty good idea what you're going to get. With the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's high-concept fall festival, Dedications (Mozart dedicated to Haydn, Schumann dedicated to Mendelssohn; Nov. 4, 6), and its higher-concept winter festival here, the title tells you little. ''Immortal investments'' refers to patronage, tributes and commissions. So there are Haydn and Beethoven quartets commissioned by Prince Lobkowitz; works by the mutual admirers Joachim and Brahms; music by Stravinsky, Debussy, Faure and others associated with salons hosted by the Princesse de Polignac; and pieces by Ravel, Bartok, Poulenc and Copland commissioned by Elizabeth Sprague Coolidge. It all fits into a season-long theme of synergy: a tough one for a marketing department to wrap its cliches around. Feb. 10; 12; 24; 26, 28. Alice Tully Hall.
'LA TRAVIATA' The newly nomadic New York City Opera finally opens its season of full productions. On a recent visit to The New York Times, administrators of the Brooklyn Academy of Music made clear that they were happy to provide a home for City Opera performances, but only if the presentations jibe with Brooklyn Academy's own programming philosophy. Verdi's war horse, for example, might not otherwise have qualified, but the director of this new production (with scenery and costumes created for the Glimmerglass Opera and the Vancouver Opera) is Jonathan Miller, whose work has generally played well at the house. Laquita Mitchell sings the title role, David Pomeroy is Alfredo, and Steven White conducts. Opens Feb. 12. BAM Howard Gilman Opera House.
CHICAGO SYMPHONY IN SAN FRANCISCO The two programs, conducted by Riccardo Muti, will be performed in Chicago first, but here they are part of an American Orchestra Series the San Francisco Symphony is presenting to celebrate its centennial. It has invited six major ensembles to perform two concerts each, including works they have commissioned. Chicago presents works by its composers in residence, Mason Bates's ''Alternative Energy'' (with Honegger's ''Pacific 231'' and Franck's Symphony in D minor) and Anna Clynes's ''Night Ferry'' (with Schubert's Ninth Symphony and an entr'acte from his incidental music for ''Rosamunde''). Other orchestras participating are the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the Boston Symphony, the Cleveland Orchestra, the New York Philharmonic and the Philadelphia Orchestra, Feb. 14, 15. Davies Symphony Hall, San Francisco, (415) 864-6000, sfsymphony.org.
'PRIMA DONNA' When challenged recently as to why, with only four productions to spare this season, the scaled-down New York City Opera would stake so much on a Rufus Wainwright opera that even some of Mr. Wainwright's staunchest admirers found wanting at its premiere in Manchester, England, in 2009, George Steel, City Opera's general manager and artistic director, rose to a spirited defense. ''It's a beautiful and remarkably accomplished work,'' he said, ''a love letter to French opera. It's never been performed in the United States, and it's precisely the kind of thing City Opera ought to perform.'' The Brooklyn Academy's administrators seem to agree. The rest will be history, of one sort or another. Opens Feb. 19. BAM Howard Gilman Opera House.
ERIK OWENS This bass-baritone turned the seemingly thankless role of Alberich in Wagner's ''Rheingold'' into a star vehicle last season. And now -- in addition to singing Alberich this season in ''Rheingold,'' ''Siegfried'' and ''Gotterdammerung'' -- Mr. Owens does what stars do, taking over the stage for a solo recital. The program includes works by Schubert, Schumann, Wolf, Debussy, Duparc, Ravel and, yes, Wagner; and the pianist, in a bit of glamour casting, is the conductor Robert Spano. Feb. 21. Zankel Hall.
BERLIN PHILHARMONIC When last heard in Carnegie, in 2009, Simon Rattle and this great orchestra had to compete with sounds intruding from a concert of Cape Verdean music in Zankel Hall. Carnegie seems to have ironed out that wrinkle in its programming strategy and made the world safe for pianissimos again. Of those there will be many (often opposite mighty fortissimos), in Debussy's ''Prelude a l'Apres-Midi d'un Faune,'' Schoenberg's ''Verklarte Nacht'' and Elgar's ''Enigma Variations'' on the first night; a completion of Bruckner's Ninth Symphony on the second; and Mahler's ''Resurrection'' Symphony on the third. Feb. 23-25. Carnegie Hall.
