LENGTH: 470 words

HEADLINE: Losing Faith in Government

BYLINE: CATHERINE RAMPELL


HIGHLIGHT: Americans' confidence in their government is at record lows. And this perception matters in the effectiveness of any policies. 

 BODY:
Washington's dysfunctional political climate not only makes it harder for Congress to pass sound economic policy. It also means that whatever policies Congress manages to pass may be ineffective anyway, since Americans have lost so much confidence in their government's ability to help.
Americans' confidence in their government is at historic lows, according to Gallup's annual governance survey.
The poll of 1,017 adults, conducted in early September, found that 81 percent of Americans are dissatisfied with the way the country is being governed, the highest share since the question was first asked in 1972.
Additionally, 69 percent of Americans say they have little or no confidence in the legislative branch of government, also a record high, and nearly three times the share of people who said this in 1972.
Americans estimate that the federal government wastes 51 cents of every dollar it spends, the highest number on record since that question was first asked in 1979. (Because the margin of sampling error was plus or minus four percentage points, however, that is not a statistically significant difference from last year's poll, when Americans said 50 cents of every dollar the government spent was wasted.)
Almost half of Americans (49 percent) believe the federal government "poses an immediate threat to the rights and freedoms of ordinary citizens." In 2003, less than a third of Americans said they believed this.
Perhaps most worrisome, Americans' trust and confidence in the government's ability to handle policy problems has plummeted.
The light green line above shows that just 43 percent of Americans say they have "a great deal or fair amount" of trust in the federal government to handle domestic problems. That is lower than it was at any time in the past four decades.
If we have another federal government shutdown in the next few days, which is entirely possible, these sentiments will only get worse.
My concern about these survey responses isn't that they might hurt politician's feelings. It's that, in order for government policy to be effective, people must it will be effective. This is as true for economic policy as it is for anything else.
In particular, part of the reason that economic stimulus works is that it gives consumers and businesses confidence that the economy will improve. That belief becomes self-fulfilling as they feel more comfortable increasing their purchases and investments.
Likewise, if Americans believe that Congress cannot be counted upon to do anything that will help the economy, nothing that Congress does -- no matter how well designed and well executed -- will succeed in helping the economy. Perception matters.

LENGTH: 672 words

HEADLINE: Malawi's Man at the U.N.

BYLINE: JAMES BARRON


HIGHLIGHT: He may be somebody back home, but in New York he's just another diplomat. 

 BODY:
On Sept. 15, just in time for the opening of the United Nations General Assembly, City Room asked a question: What nation that you probably wouldn't hear about would you like to hear about? Or, more precisely, what nation's diplomats would you like to find out about?
One nation that came to mind was Malawi,one of the world's poorest countries. It was last in the news in July when antigovernment protests left at least 19 people dead. The president, Bingu wa Mutharika, a former World Bank economist who had been credited with reducing hunger in his country of 16 million, tired of dissent and demonstrations and warned that he did not want protesters returning to the streets. "I'll go after you," he was quoted as saying. "Even if you hide in holes, I'll smoke you out."
Britain suspended aid to the Malawi government, and a United States foreign aid agency put a $350 million grant on hold, where it remains. 
Malawi's representative to the United Nations, Ambassador Brian G. Bowler, 46, arrived in June 2010 after postings in India, Belgium, the European Union, France, Switzerland, Luxembourg and Holland. He said that during the General Assembly, he had been focused on Malawi's role as one of 19 vice presidents, a role that put him in charge of the session on Friday afternoon when the president of the newest member nation, South Sudan, took the floor for the first time.
"That was moving for me personally," Mr. Bowler said. "It was a great moment to welcome South Sudan."
He said diplomats from small nations go almost unnoticed in New York. And there is no special notice for them when they arrive: no expedited process to whisk them through immigrations and customs. Nor is there a security detail once they take up their routine in Manhattan.
"When it comes to entering J.F.K., the rigamarole you have to go through," Ambassador Bowler said. "The visa says 'foreign minister of a foreign country.' It doesn't take the archbishop of Canterbury to work it out, but they don't get it. I'm not knocking the system. I think they're doing it for a very good reason. They have experience that's shown it's necessary. It's the way they're doing it. It's a style."
Mr. Bowler, who said Malawi was a major producer of burley tobacco -a light-colored variety also grown in parts of the United States- said that he had not met Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who addressed the General Assembly last week and mentioned, among other things, the city's efforts to fight smoking. The city says 14 percent of New Yorkers smoke now, compared with nearly 22 percent in 2002.
"We support the drive to fight cancer," Mr. Bowler said, "but we've got a double whammy. Our main foreign currency earner is tobacco. Having to come up with an alternate crop, it's like going to the Caribbean and telling people, 'Don't fish.' But the warning shots have been fired. Tobacco is on the way out."
As long as tobacco is still being grown, however, the West should consider its effects on people who handle it, Mr. Bowler said.
"In Africa, children handle tobacco from 5 years old on," he said, "but we didn't know this when the white man brought the crop across. Very few Africans smoke. We know to grow the tobacco and send it. They've created the patch, which is nicotine absorbed through the skin. The leaf is pure, straight, hard-core nicotine. A child by the time he's 10 could have as much nicotine as a 40- or 50-year-old smoker. One of my pleas would be to put money into research to come up with tangible statistics and some kind of program to address Malawians and Zimbabweans with young cancers."
His days have been a whirl of meetings and receptions. One night last week, Mr. Bowler was invited to five social events in five different places around the city. "It's glamorous because there are all the dinners with all the right people," he said, "but you have to leverage it. There are opportunities for networking and strategizing."

(Bats)

PUB-DATE: September 26, 2011

SECTION: SPORTS; baseball

LENGTH: 659 words

HEADLINE: Leyland Reveals What's Beneath Crusty Exterior

BYLINE: JOANNE C. GERSTNER


HIGHLIGHT: Detroit Tigers Manager Jim Leyland explained in an interview with the Detroit News why the Tigers' success has been emotional for him. 

 BODY:
Detroit Tigers manager Jim Leyland's reputation as a rough hewn baseball character comes from his sometimes testy exchanges with the news media, umpires and his own players. It doesn't help that some of these exchanges occur when he has his mouth full of food during postgame news conferences in his office.
But an emotional, reflective softie poked out from beneath that exterior with his emotional reaction to the Tigers clinching their first American League Central title since 1987 on Sept. 16. On Monday, Leyland, 66, talked about his life, his ways, and his image during a wide-ranging interview with the Detroit News.
"When you have this position, you have to be a little crusty," Leyland said. "If you don't, you're going to get eaten alive - by players, by media, by the fans .Is some of it planned? Absolutely. You have to be that way sometimes or you're going to get chewed up. But my dad was one of 16 kids. My wife was one of 11. I'm one of seven, so I know what it's all about. I've worn my brothers' shoes and vice versa. And I'm proud of that. To me, that's America."
Leyland, a native of Perrysburg, Ohio, and not far from Detroit, understands the economic pain the area has gone through. The Tigers' success has brought a festive atmosphere to Comerica Park, and fans are gobbling up playoff tickets. He said he sees the enthusiasm around baseball and is grateful for the fans' support.
" My dad was a factory worker. I worked in a factory," Leyland said. "I know what it's like for my dad trying to feed seven kids and worrying if the plant was going to shut down, or move to another place. Is there going to be a strike, are there going to be layoffs? I know what that's about.
"And these people (Tigers fans), what they've gone through to keep coming out here, that's unbelieveable. I was totally being sincere. And it is emotional for me."
Leyland continued, "I'm not ashamed to say I had brothers who worked in the factory and I had to borrow money from them to have enough gas money to get to spring training when I was in the minor leagues some years .That's just the way it was. You know, I know what it's all about I don't know all the technicalities of the auto industry, but I do know people are getting up at 5 o'clock in the morning and sweating their tails off, hoping they don't lose their jobs next week or have to live off unemployment. That's not easy."
Leyland and General Manager Dave Dombrowski took daily fire from fans and pundits early in the season when it seemed the Tigers were doomed to another lackluster year. Leyland received a one-year contract extension in August and Dombrowski made a few key trades for outfielder Delmon Young, starter Doug Fister and infielder Wilson Betemit.
The Tigers have had six managers, including Leyland, since the late Sparky Anderson left in 1995. Leyland was hired in 2006, and took the Tigers to the World Series that same season. He was asked if he worried about being fired this season.
" The Tigers hadn't had a real good track record about changing managers for a lot of years. And it didn't work too good," Leyland said. "So, all of a sudden, it doesn't matter that it was me. Doesn't matter who's in this chair. But it looked as if their answer for a lot of years was to just change managers. It doesn't work that way. You have to be solid in an organization. And you have to believe in your guy. And if the time comes when you don't, obviously, you should make a change.
"But just to make a change to appease the media and the talk shows isn't always the answer. And I think they found that out. And it has nothing to do with Jim Leyland. I mean, before they had Buddy Bell, Larry Parrish, Phil Garner, Luis Pujols, Alan Trammell - all these guys, and it wasn't that they were bad guys or bad managers. They weren't. But it's not the answer every time something goes wrong. The easy thing to do is get rid of the manager and say, "We need a change." It doesn't work that way."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

The New York Times Blogs
(The Learning Network)

PUB-DATE: September 26, 2011

SECTION: EDUCATION

LENGTH: 1712 words

HEADLINE: What We Eat, Where We Sleep: Documenting Daily Life to Tell Stories

BYLINE: KATHERINE SCHULTEN


HIGHLIGHT: Ideas for using two photo slide shows, each focusing on one aspect of the daily lives of people around the world, to have students explore what the way we eat and where we sleep say about who we are. 

 BODY:
In August, two slide shows were published on NYTimes.com that both seemed so useful for classrooms that we saved them until the school year began to present together in a lesson.
On the Well blog, Tara Parker-Pope featured 15 photos from a book called "What I Eat: Around the World in 80 Diets" that has become an exhibit at the Museum of Science in Boston. Here's how she described it:
In an unusual project, Peter Menzel and Faith D'Alusio, a photographer and writer, traveled the world collecting photos and stories about what people eat in a day. They documented the meager meals of a Masai goat herder during a drought, the fast-food diet of an American long-haul trucker and a veritable feast of lamb kebabs and other foods set out by an Iranian bread baker.
Meanwhile, the Lens blog introduced 20 photos from a book called "Where Children Sleep":
Mr. Mollison's new book, "Where Children Sleep," had its origins in a project undertaken for a children's charity several years ago. As he considered how to represent needy children around the world, he wanted to avoid the common devices: pleading eyes, toothless smiles. When he visualized his own childhood, he realized that his bedroom said a lot about what sort of life he led. So he set out to find others.
Here are some ideas for using these extraordinary photos across the curriculum - and some suggestions for including other Times features in which the details of everyday life become an anthropological lens.
Before Viewing
What do the ordinary details of our daily lives say about who we are, where we're from and what we care about?
Have students create two lists: on one side of the page, a list of 10 things they remember eating the day before; on the other, a list of 10 things people would see if they walked into that student's bedroom. (If you're only working with one slide show, have students compile only the list that corresponds to it.)
Next, have students work with a partner to compare their lists. Ask partners to discuss these questions: 1) What do you think these lists say about who you are, where you live and what you care about? 2) If, one hundred years from now, a historian or anthropologist was to come upon your lists, what might he or she conclude about you, your life and where you're from? What questions might he or she have?
Have the whole class share observations, then show one or both slide shows, using the questions below.
Questions
What photographs interested or surprised you most? Why? What questions did those photos raise for you?What can these photos tell you about the lives of the people pictured? What do you think they can't tell you?What does the photographer for the food series, Peter Menzel, mean when he says, "We present information to people rather than drawing conclusions ... we're trying to educate readers by show and tell"? Could that apply to both sets of photos?In her post about the children's bedrooms series, Kerri Macdonald writes, "As much as the project is about the quirkiness of childhood, it is, more strikingly, a commentary on class and on poverty. But the diversity also provides a sense of togetherness." Where can you see examples of both the social commentary and the "sense of togetherness" in both series?How would you contrast the two series? To what extent are they trying to do the same thing? How do they differ?
Activity Ideas
"Imagine gathering all the food you plan to eat today. Now take a picture of it." So begins Tara Parker-Pope's post about the photographs of food. You might be inspired by the simplicity of this description to take photos of your own bedroom or the food you'll eat in a day, or you might go out into your community and, using these photos as a model, create a similar series featuring people you know.
Or, you could choose another lens through which to depict the universal. Another project the Well blog post describes, for instance, is "Material World," in which families are pictured with their most precious possessions. You could photograph children with their favorite toys; teenagers in their most-loved t-shirts; people with the cars, bikes, skateboards, buss passes or other means of transportation they use every day; or people with their pets. Students might work in pairs to interview each subject as well and write up a short piece to accompany each photo.
As a class, establish a theme, whether "eating," "holidays," "identity," "family" or anything else, and invite everyone to bring in one or more photos from their own or their family's photo albums that illustrate it. Mount them all, then, as a class, write up an introduction that highlights some of the interesting connections you see between the photos. Invite others to view your photo gallery and leave comments - or even contribute their own photographs!
We have published many lessons in the past that invite students to analyze photographs. Adapt the guiding questions and worksheets from Who Is Family? Analyzing Family Photos or from Critical Lenses to find ways to consider the technical and artistic aspects of these photographs.
In both series, there are photos of people who live in the same place but represent different ways of living there. Choose two photos to compare - either from the same series or, perhaps, one from each series. What do the differences tell you? What questions about class, poverty, gender or other issues does the comparison raise? How might you represent differences like this in your own community through two photographs?
Is there a place or way of life depicted in these photos that especially intrigues you? Use online and library resources to explore that place, using the details depicted in the photo to generate research questions. As you go, make a list of questions you'd like to ask a real person from that area, then attempt to connect with someone your age who lives there via a site like e-pals. (In a recent edutopia post "World Without Walls: Learning Well With Others," Will Richardson offers other suggestions for connection classrooms and students.)
David Rabkin, director of current science and technology at the Boston Museum of Science, explains why the photo series about food has been popular at his museum:
"Food is a hot topic - people are interested in it and its many dimensions, from its health impact, to the experience of great food, to the bigger picture of our global food system and issues of social justice...Food is personal. It's a great topic for our museum because it's so compelling to so many of our visitors and so rich in terms of the educational directions in which we can go with them."
Using these photos as inspiration, brainstorm as many "dimensions" of the overall topic "food" as you can, then choose one you'd like to learn more about.
For almost any aspect you can think of, Times Topics pages will be a good place to start. For instance, if you're investigating the question of whether junk food is really cheaper to eat than healthy food, you might start with the recent graphic accompanying Mark Bittman's column on that question that visually compares prices for different meals.
Create an infographic depicting what you find.
In an interactive feature that accompanies the article "Three Generations Under One Roof," Sarah Kramer explores the lives of an extended family of Chinese-Americans living together in a house in New York City. Here is a quote from the article that vividly lists the details of this family's everyday life:
Life happens here on Forsyth Street: drum lessons for the teenagers on Thursday nights; religious school for Warren and Jen's boys on Sunday mornings; grilling on the roof deck in summer; and hip-hop, swimming, tutoring, soccer games, piano and guitar lessons and the occasional rooftop water fight sprinkled in. Food is bought in bulk: 25-pound bags of rice, 15 pounds of beef. It takes three gallons of milk, more than five pounds of salad greens and up to a dozen loads of laundry to keep the household running each week. Filling the home are seven children, ages 4 through 17; three iPads; 10 computers; 14 bicycles; two Cantonese-speaking baby sitters and a home aide; three languages (English, Spanish, Cantonese); one cat (another was recently euthanized); and a revolving door of friends.
Using just this paragraph as a model - and perhaps using "Life happens here on [name of street]" as a "sentence starter" - write your own short description of how "life happens" at your house. Then, use a video camera as Ms. Kramer does to capture a span of time (perhaps 15 minutes of your breakfast or dinner routine) in your home. What does the footage show that surprises you? Why?
In 2010, the Magazine published "The Shrine Down the Hall," a series of photos of the bedrooms of American soldiers lost in war. We created a lesson plan around that series that might be used with the "Where Children Sleep" series. Students might also consider memorializing a loss of their own by photographing or writing about how daily life is affected by the change they have experienced.
Many teachers will already know the George Ella Lyon list-form poem "Where I'm From." As Mr. Lyon writes, "People have used it at their family reunions, teachers have used it with kids all over the United States, in Ecuador and China; they have taken it to girls in juvenile detention, to men in prison for life, and to refugees in a camp in the Sudan." On his Web site, he features the poem along with ideas for writing from it. A "Where I'm From" poem could easily be a companion or extension to the photography, writing or video projects suggested above.
Related Lessons and Student Opinion Questions From the Learning Network:
Lesson | Picture This! Building Photo-Based Writing Skills
Lesson | From Dr. Spock to the Tiger Mother: Studying Parents and Families
Lesson | Cook, Eat Love? Learning to Prepare Nutritious Meals
Lesson | Organic, Slow or Local: Exploring Food-Based Communities
Lesson | Just a Moment: Photographing Ordinary Life
Student Opinion | How Do You Define 'Family'?
Student Opinion | How Much Food Does Your Family Waste?

        
A Food-Photographing Phenomenon
        
Who Is Family? Analyzing Family Photos
        
What Do You Wish Your Teachers Knew About You?
        
Adolescent Health | Nutrition, Healthy Weight and Eating Disorders
        
Snapshot of the American Household

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: News

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Web Blog

SUBJECT: STUDENTS & STUDENT LIFE (90%); HUMANITIES & SOCIAL SCIENCE (90%); PHOTOGRAPHY (90%); ANTHROPOLOGY & ARCHAEOLOGY (89%); EXHIBITIONS (78%); CURRICULA (78%); WRITERS (78%); TEACHING MATERIALS & MEDIA (78%); PHOTOJOURNALISM (77%); VISUAL ARTISTS (77%); HISTORY (76%); MUSEUMS & GALLERIES (76%); JOURNALISM (75%); CHARITIES (66%) family; Food; Photography; Biographies; Culture and Identity; Economics; Environment and Society; Geography; Health; Journalism; Language Arts; Lesson Plans; Media Studies; Multimedia; Nutrition; Personal Economics; Photojournalism; Social Studies; Visual Literacy; World Cultures and Traditions

Create an infographic depicting what you find.
In an interactive feature that accompanies the article "Three Generations Under One Roof," Sarah Kramer explores the lives of an extended family of Chinese-Americans living together in a house in New York City. Here is a quote from the article that vividly lists the details of this family's everyday life:
Life happens here on Forsyth Street: drum lessons for the teenagers on Thursday nights; religious school for Warren and Jen's boys on Sunday mornings; grilling on the roof deck in summer; and hip-hop, swimming, tutoring, soccer games, piano and guitar lessons and the occasional rooftop water fight sprinkled in. Food is bought in bulk: 25-pound bags of rice, 15 pounds of beef. It takes three gallons of milk, more than five pounds of salad greens and up to a dozen loads of laundry to keep the household running each week. Filling the home are seven children, ages 4 through 17; three iPads; 10 computers; 14 bicycles; two Cantonese-speaking baby sitters and a home aide; three languages (English, Spanish, Cantonese); one cat (another was recently euthanized); and a revolving door of friends.
Using just this paragraph as a model - and perhaps using "Life happens here on [name of street]" as a "sentence starter" - write your own short description of how "life happens" at your house. Then, use a video camera as Ms. Kramer does to capture a span of time (perhaps 15 minutes of your breakfast or dinner routine) in your home. What does the footage show that surprises you? Why?
In 2010, the Magazine published "The Shrine Down the Hall," a series of photos of the bedrooms of American soldiers lost in war. We created a lesson plan around that series that might be used with the "Where Children Sleep" series. Students might also consider memorializing a loss of their own by photographing or writing about how daily life is affected by the change they have experienced.
Many teachers will already know the George Ella Lyon list-form poem "Where I'm From." As Mr. Lyon writes, "People have used it at their family reunions, teachers have used it with kids all over the United States, in Ecuador and China; they have taken it to girls in juvenile detention, to men in prison for life, and to refugees in a camp in the Sudan." On his Web site, he features the poem along with ideas for writing from it. A "Where I'm From" poem could easily be a companion or extension to the photography, writing or video projects suggested above.

SECTION: HEALTH

LENGTH: 616 words

HEADLINE: Illinois Halts Inquiries of Nonprofit Hospitals

BYLINE: BRUCE JAPSEN


HIGHLIGHT: The state Revenue Department, acceding to a request from the governor, said it would refrain from challenging property tax exemptions for more hospitals until recommendations can be made. 

 BODY:
The Illinois Revenue Department said on Monday that it had agreed to hold off on challenging any more hospital tax exemptions after Gov. Pat Quinn said he wanted a reprieve to allow the industry and state officials to come up with recommendations outlining how much charity care hospitals should provide to justify not paying property taxes.
The postponement comes after the department last month moved to strip property tax exemptions from three of the state's better known hospitals, saying they did not provide enough charity care. The state said Northwestern Memorial HealthCare's Prentice Women's Hospital in Chicago, Edward Hospital Naperville and Decatur (Ill.) Memorial Hospital were providing free and discounted medical care that ranged from 0.96 percent to 1.85 percent of their patient-care revenue.
"The department's recent decisions have created great concern and uncertainty among the hospital community," the governor wrote in a letter last week to MaryJane Wurth, the hospital association president.
Mr. Quinn set a March 1, 2012, deadline for recommendations on what the parties, including the state Attorney General Lisa Madigan and Brian Hamer, director of the Revenue Department, should allow for nonprofit hospitals to justify their tax exemptions.
That means about 15 hospital systems that await rulings on their tax exemptions can rest easy for now that they won't have their tax status challenged.
"We are willing to pause issuing these orders while talks are productive and moving forward," Sue Hofer, a spokeswoman for Mr. Hamer, said Monday.
The Revenue Department acted to strip the exemptions following a ruling last year by the State Supreme Court upholding the revocation of the property tax exemption for Catholic-owned Provena Covenant Medical Center in downstate Urbana. For that hospital, the value of charity care provided to indigent patients amounted to less than 1 percent of its revenue in 2002.
Though the Illinois Supreme Court ruled Provena's charity care level was not enough, it did not establish a specific threshold.
The hospitals argue that their contributions are significant, even though charity care is a small percentage of their business. Hospitals seek a broader definition of charity care that goes beyond just charity care and expand to include patients' unpaid debts, costs of medical care not covered by Medicare or Medicaid and direct costs that teaching hospitals pay to train doctors and conduct research.
The battle comes during a period of high unemployment and related loss in health benefits by millions of Americans that analysts say are in greater need for discounted and free medical care. Meanwhile, hospitals could face a different problem in 2014 when federal health care legislation, if it becomes fully effective, covers 30 million more Americans and therefore would make it difficult for some hospitals to provide higher levels of charity care.
The issue has also been important on the federal level where Senator Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, has for years criticized charity care levels at hospitals and pushed for higher percentages to justify tax exemptions.
Mr. Quinn said he was not attempting to thwart the work of the Revenue Department in its challenge of tax exemptions for the Northwestern, Decatur or Edward hospitals. Those cases, which are expected to be appealed in the next month, are moving ahead, the department said.
If talks between state officials and hospitals fail to come up with satisfactory recommendations by March 1, Mr. Quinn's office said it expected the Revenue Department to proceed with its reviews. "This is not an open-ended hold," said Brie Callahan, a spokeswoman for the governor.

SECTION: BUSINESS

LENGTH: 928 words

HEADLINE: Goldman Sachs Draws Up Deeper Cuts

BYLINE: SUSANNE CRAIG and KEVIN ROOSE


HIGHLIGHT: Goldman Sachs is preparing to significantly expand its cost-cutting initiative, a move that could lead to additional job losses at the bank. 

 BODY:
Goldman Sachs, bracing for what could be one of its worst quarters since it went public 12 years ago, is preparing to expand its cost-cutting initiative by hundreds of millions of dollars, a move that could lead to additional job losses at the Wall Street bank.
 This summer, Goldman said that it would wring out $1.2 billion in costs from its operations by mid-2012 and cut roughly 1,000 jobs, about 3 percent of its work force. But as the market turmoil has weighed on trading and other businesses in recent weeks, senior executives have been debating even deeper reductions, according to people briefed on the matter who were not authorized to speak publicly. 
 With the company's third quarter closing on Friday, Goldman has been revising its plans, potentially raising the cuts by as much as $250 million, to $1.45 billion. Based on its 2010 spending, such reductions would amount to 5 percent of the firm's expenses.
Along with the possibility of additional layoffs, the firm is expected to reduce employee pay, much of which is handed out later in the year. It is also sharpening its focus on noncompensation expenses, like real estate and travel, according to one of the executives with knowledge of the discussions.
The executive warned that no final decision had been made on size of the cuts, and that the numbers could change quickly if the market improved or weakened. The financial firm may address the matter when it releases its earnings on Oct. 18, he added.
Goldman's move underscores the broader problems on Wall Street. Financial firms have been under pressure for months, amid the European debt crisis and an economic slowdown in the United States, and a raft of regulatory changes is expected to crimp future profits. But the financial situation has deteriorated in recent weeks, as the market rout has ravaged revenue across Wall Street.
 With the stock market slumping, analysts are quickly revising their estimates for third quarter earnings, which the banks are set to report in mid-October. Analysts are tempering their predictions for JPMorgan Chase, Morgan Stanley, Citigroup, Bank of America and others. Goldman is now expected to earn $1.35 a share in the third quarter, less than half what the firm earned in the same period of 2010, according to consensus estimates from Thomson Reuters. A month ago, analysts predicted the bank would make $2.65 a share.
 The financial picture could be even more bleak, as analysts at both Barclays Capital and Bank of America Merrill Lynch have predicted a loss for Goldman. The company has reported a quarterly loss only once since going public in 1999; it lost $2.12 billion in the fourth quarter of 2008, months after Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy.
"This is an extremely challenging environment, and I am sure every bank will be taking another hard look at expenses after the recent market downturn," said Glenn Schorr, an analyst at Nomura, the Japanese bank. 
In anticipation of a slowdown, banks began trimming their budgets earlier this year and took aim at the biggest expense: compensation. Bank of America, which continues to have losses from the mortgage crisis, has had some of the most severe cuts. It has announced that it would eliminate 30,000 jobs, nearly 10 percent of its total work force, over the next few years. Over all, the bank is looking to cut $5 billion in annual expenses.
JPMorgan Chase is in the midst of a five-year, $1.3 billion cost-cutting plan that will eliminate roughly 3,000 jobs. Morgan Stanley cut some low-producing brokers in its wealth management division, and Credit Suisse laid off administrative assistants in its investment banking unit last week as part of a larger reduction of 2,000 employees. 
Wall Street executives are also preparing their staffs for smaller year-end bonuses, although the change is not yet reflected in the expenses. During the first six months of the year Citigroup, JPMorgan, Goldman, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America set aside $65.69 billion to cover compensation and benefits, up 8 percent from a year ago, according to data provided by Nomura. But financial firms tend to wait until the fourth quarter to make the call on the annual payouts.
"The third quarter was rough and revenue is sure to be down, so compensation levels will follow," said Mr. Schorr.
As Wall Street looks to drive down costs in a bid to protect profits, no expense has been overlooked. Goldman Sachs recently downsized the drinking cups in its New York headquarters to 10 ounces from 12 ounces, saving thousands of dollars. It has also gone mostly cashless in the cafeteria and other areas, eliminating the need to pay armored truck companies to haul away the money.
Barclays, which has said it plans to cut 3,000 jobs this year, recently issued a memo reminding employees that work-issued cellphones are to be used "for valid business purposes only." In addition to closing two-thirds of its 63 data centers, Bank of America did not host an annual field day for its municipal bond department, a country club affair in New Jersey that in past years included sport stations outfitted with beer kegs.
 Even foliage is not safe from the chopping block. James P. Gorman, the chief executive of Morgan Stanley, faced questions about plants at a town hall meeting this summer. An employee told Mr. Gorman that he had noticed decidedly less greenery around the office.
"Every dollar we don't spent is a dollar available for the bottom line," Mr. Gorman responded.

LENGTH: 1753 words

HEADLINE: This Week in Small Business: Twisting Our Wealth Away

BYLINE: GENE MARKS


HIGHLIGHT: Plus: Does your business keep you up at night? 

 BODY:
What's affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week. 
The Fed: Let's Do the Twist
The Fed considers "Operation Twist." Paul A. Volcker warns to beware of inflation. Republican leaders plead with the Fed not to make any more moves. The Fed gets pessimistic and makes the move - and the markets plunge (and plunge again).
The Deficit 1: Obama Reveals His Plan
President Obama proposes a $3 trillion deficit-cutting plan, asking for a $3 tax increase for every $1 in cost cuts. The Brookings Institution's William Gale summarizes here. Rick Newman lists the plan's biggest losers. Keith Hennessey thinks it contains a lot of gimmicks. The Economist says it's all politics: "Even if the plan offered today goes nowhere, it is a document he can carry proudly into the election to portray Republicans as unrepentant friends of the rich, a message that, judging from recent polls, resonates with the public." David Brooks says he's an Obama sap. Kel Munger says "things aren't going to get better without jobs, and if our corporate overlords are not going to pull their own economic weight by putting their profits back into the economy, the only other option is to tax the incredibly wealthy." Margaret Thatcher weighs in. House Democrats introduce a bill to eliminate the debt ceiling. At least this congressman's around in case anyone has a heart attack.
The Deficit 2: The Tax Effects
Ezra Klein thinks antitax supporters should be happy with the president's plan: "There's no doubt that the antitax types aren't happy with Obama's proposal but they have a lot to be happy with given the direction of the general debate." Steve Benen says that President Obama has cut more taxes than President George W. Bush. The plan includes a provision for back taxes owed by contractors to be deducted from federal contract payments. Loren Steffy wants broader-based tax reform. And (of course) Robert Reich wants to raise the top tax rate to 70 percent.
The Deficit 3: Oh No, Not Again
Another government shutdown looms (but this will make you smile).
The Economy: Squeegees Return
Eswar Prasad worries that the global economic recovery is in real danger of skidding off course. John Judis says our economic nightmare is just beginning. Another ominous sign: the return of squeegees to New York. American firms continue to hoard cash and overall bank deposits soar despiterock-bottom interest rates. A Gallup poll finds that 60 percent of Americans don't expect the economy to improve soon. Most Americans feel they'll never be millionaires. Phil Gyford asks why we even bother to make economic forecasts. The International Monetary Fund, he says, "has issued four different forecasts about growth for 2011. It has changed its mind three times in nine months. Its most recent forecast is half its original one."
Finance: Will We See Those Billions?
Thirteen banks, including Citigroup and Regions Financial, pledge billions for small businesses. That's nice, but a new report says banks are largely passing over small businesses. Miranda Marquit explains how to choose the right credit card for your business. Manchester Unitedholds up its initial public offering. This guy has been holding up his arm for the past 38 years. American Express offers a new plan for merchants toreceive access to up to $750,000 in financing.
Data: It's Good to Be the Professor
More goods are leaving West Coast ports. Corporate officers are making less but Ph.D.'s are making more (anyone have kids in college?). Builder confidence declines slightly. Housing starts fall again, but architectural billings gain the most in four years. And real estate prices rise. Oracle's profit is up 36 percent. The commercial printing industry has risen seven quarters in a row. The Philadelphia Fed reports continued weakness. August economic indicators signal weak growth. Unemployment claims stay above 400,000.
Marketing: And the Most Important Question Is ?
After a study says its "App Economy" contributes more than $15 billion to the American economy, Facebook offers new incentives for small business. But Gawker says Facebook is driving us to drink. A social media strategist explains why small businesses worry about social media. Jeremy Epstein explains how invoices can go viral. A start-up introduces an app to identify how many customers are installing apps and what advertising channel influenced the user. Christopher Mims says negative reviews can increase your online sales. Patrick Garmoe offers 14 ways to build an army of adoring journalists via Twitter. Here's how you can get noticed this holiday shopping season. Amanda DiSilvestro explains how e-books canhelp us market.
Technology 1: Google Wallet Arrives
Google Wallet is here. Visa, American Express and Discover join up. Katie reviews. The bloggers at allbusiness.com aren't sure it's worth it yet.
Technology 2: Netflix Exercises "Management"
Nielsen ranks the top 20 Android apps. And here are the five best online backup applicationsfor small businesses. Ever wonder how people use their smartphones? Jason Keith says QR codes aren't ready for prime time: "Big retailers like Macy's, Tommy Hilfiger and the Gap have used them successfully, but the time and effort that it takes to ensure you get a good return on investment is big." Netflix's Reed Hastings exercises what some call management. Tim Carmody says Google+ suddenly looks pretty busy for a ghost town. Dell introduces a preconfigured virtualization solution for smaller companies.
Your People: Rise Early, Avoid Dumplings
Andy gets promoted. A new report finds that "63 percent of those who are self-employed would not consider changing jobs in the next 12 months, but less than half (48 percent) are actually satisfied with their job, and only 28 percent would recommend self-employment to others." Harvey Schachter reveals six rules for keeping employees engaged. Early risers may be thinner and happier. In a related story a man wins a dumpling-eating contest, then dies. Here are 10 crazy rules that could get you fired from Amazon's warehouse.
Around the States: California Loses Again
Batman increases Pennsylvania's employment. A micro documentary looks at the start-up community in D.C. Some Orlando-area small companies find ways to survive the shuttle's demise. Joel Kotkin sees the demise of the "luxury city" of New York. Unemployment rates rise most in Nevada, California and Florida. Another report finds California is the worst for business. Giant snails invade a Miami neighborhood. A congressman hosts a small-business summit in Louisiana.
Start-Up: Sun, Grub and $50 Million
A solar start-up and a food delivery search engine each raise $50 million. An entrepreneur explains why he moved to Hong Kong to start his business and another is convinced that his start-up has the potential toremake the national economy. Rich Aberman explains how not to recruit for a start-up.
Ideas: Apps of Prosperity
A toilet paper roll the Beatles refused to use while recording could sell for 1,000 per sheet. Seven are inducted into the entrepreneur's walk of fame. Niall Ferguson gives a TED talk on the six killer apps of prosperity. Annie Lowrey explains why small businesses aren't innovative: "Few spend any money on research or development, getting a patent, or otherwise trademarking a new idea. Most simply help provide already-crowded markets with familiar goods such as legal work or gas or nearby groceries." Mark Cuban says the most patriotic thing you can do is to go out there and get rich (and pay taxes). Here are some of the best undergrad and graduate entrepreneurial studies programs.
Around the World: Russians Duke It Out
American dependence on foreign oil is the lowestsince 1996. A couple of Russian C.E.O.'s duke it out. Confucius would be 2,562 years old this week. In his honor, 66 Chinese kidsstuff themselves into a minivan, the United States files a trade complaint and President Obama commits a photo faux pas. Italy earns a downgrade. Oh, and in case you're interested, here's how to do business in Libya.
Red Tape Update: How Does Big Sugar Get Its Way?
This journeymay have had a happy ending, but here's the warning: "a small-business owner should not have to rely upon the chance encounter, or divine intervention, of an empathetic officer in dealing with the I.R.S." Virginia Chamlee explains how Big Sugargets its way: "The majority of sugar cane might be grown in South Florida, but the industry's political reach extends far beyond the state." Robert Wood is concerned that the I.R.S. is making independent contractor reporting rules even harder.
The Week Ahead
Data this week should be interesting: we'll get reports on new and pending home sales, durable goods orders and personal spending and income. Also, both the Conference Board and the University of Michigan will release consumer-confidence information.
This Week's Bests
Things to Do When Business Is Slow. Debra Ellis offers five suggestions, including "Clean house": "The roll-up-your-sleeves deep cleaning that brightens a room, clears out in-boxes, and organizes files is best done by the people using the space. Make it a fun project by having a friendly competition where the best job wins a prize (gift cards, dinner out, extra vacation day, etc.)."
Reason We're Not Sleeping. Jason Freedman explains why entrepreneurs can't sleep. One theory is "Entrepreneurs need to focus. Night is simply more productive.": "At night, no one bothers you and you can focus for eight-hour chunks. One of the reasons I didn't care about the morning start time was that our guys were being so damn productive at night. And more productive than normal people. In fact, for a period we tried a normal schedule and it destroyed our productivity."
Way to Use Payments to Drive Revenue. A pricing strategist, Rafi Mohammed, suggests new options: "The resurrection of layaway by Wal-Mart and other retailers is simply an attempt to meet the pricing needs of customers. By the way, notice how this pricing plan does not involve margin-lowering discounts? Instead, it increases profits by charging additional premiums or fees, as well as better serving and attracting new customers. Now that's win-win."
This Week's Question: Does your business keep you up at night?

PUB-DATE: September 26, 2011

SECTION: US; politics

LENGTH: 834 words

HEADLINE: At Fund-Raisers, Obama Refers to Audiences at G.O.P. Debates

BYLINE: JACKIE CALMES


HIGHLIGHT: In a series of West Coast fund-raising events on Sunday, President Obama criticized views held by the Republican Party's conservative base, and stressed that the coming election would be "a contest of values." 

 BODY:
President Obama on Sunday criticized not only the Republicans vying to defeat him but also their party's conservative base - symbolized by the audiences at recent candidate debates -- in a busy day of four West Coast fund-raisers to collect money and rally dispirited Democratic donors.
In Woodside, Calif., an affluent community between San Francisco and San Jose, Mr. Obama hit his stump-speech theme that the 2012 election will be "a contest of values," and then suggested that some in his audience might well be former Republicans "puzzled by what's happening to that party."
"I mean, has anybody been watching the debates lately?" he asked. Referring to Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, who has sought federal aid to fight wildfires caused by a prolonged drought, Mr. Obama said: "You've got a governor whose state is on fire denying climate change. It's true. You've got audiences cheering at the prospect of somebody dying because they don't have health care and booing a service member in Iraq because they're gay."
"That's not reflective of who we are," Mr. Obama said. "This is a choice about the fundamental direction of our country." Obama advisers in the past have said he does not watch Republicans' debates. But by his remarks, Mr. Obama showed he is well aware that a recent string of debates produced moments in which reactions from audiences of Tea Party sympathizers became as widely discussed afterward as anything the candidates said - prompting some of the candidates to distance themselves later from the expressions of intolerance or hardheartedness. Besides the episodes Mr. Obama cited, at another debate the loudest applause came at the mention of the numerous executions Mr. Perry has sanctioned.
To the relief of many Democrats, Mr. Obama has become more assertive lately in attacking Republicans and drawing contrasts with them. At Sunday's first fund-raiser, one of two in the Seattle area, he said a Republican president would institute "an approach to government that would fundamentally cripple America in meeting the challenges of the 21st century."
Depending on the event, donors gave from $100 to $35,800. Those in Woodside, on the expansive and sumptuously landscaped lawn of John W. Thompson, chairman of Symantec, gave the maximum amount, to be split between the Democratic Party and Mr. Obama's reelection campaign. He addressed them as "my stockholders."
There and elsewhere, Mr. Obama acknowledged that many of the donors would probably pay higher taxes after 2012 under his proposals to raise taxes on high-income households, both to offset the short-term costs of his job-creation plan in Congress and to reduce future annual budget deficits. Citing Republicans' criticism that his proposals amount to "class warfare," Mr. Obama delivered what has become his standard response - he is a proud warrior for the middle class - and drew applause.
Celebrities made appearances at several events. Lady Gaga was at the final function, held at the Atherton, Calif., home of Sheryl Sandberg, an executive of Facebook who was a Treasury official in the Clinton administration. The singer, extravagantly attired as usual, was about two feet taller than Mr. Obama thanks to her towering heels and upswept hair.
The musician Bruce Hornsby performed at the Woodside fund-raiser. And the former pro basketball players Bill Russell and Lenny Wilkens introduced Mr. Obama at Seattle's Paramount Theater. At each stop, Mr. Obama gave a rundown of his administration's record, including taking credit for rescuing the economy, decimating Al Qaeda and killing Osama bin Laden, ending the "don't ask, don't tell" policy against openly gay service members, tightening financial industry regulations and - "as long as I get a second term" - implementation of the law expanding health insurance.
But Mr. Obama acknowledged that many Democrats, especially liberals, are disheartened that he has not been more successful in overcoming the obstructions of Congressional Republicans. "Shake off any doldrums," he told supporters at the Seattle theater, and "get to work."
In Woodside, he urged donors to "push back" against friends and neighbors whose criticisms are based on "inadequate information" from Fox News or Wall Street Journal editorials. "And in some cases," he told them, "I may need you to have some arguments with our progressive friends."
"We're going to have a stark choice in this election," Mr. Obama added. "But I have to make sure that our side is as passionate and as motivated and is working just as hard as the folks on the other side because this is a contest of values."
Quoting his vice president, "my friend Joe Biden," Mr. Obama said, "Don't compare me to the almighty, compare me to the alternative."

HEADLINE: The Wages of Bad Macroeconomics

BYLINE: PAUL KRUGMAN


HIGHLIGHT: About that currency debasement ... 

 BODY:
What you missed if you believed that the bond vigilantes were coming any day now, that rates would soar as soon as Bernanke ended QE2, and all that: Betting on Bernanke Returns 28% for Treasuries.
Betting on Ben S. Bernanke has been the most profitable trade for government bond investors in 16 years, defying lawmakers in the U.S. and abroad who said the Federal Reserve chairman's policies would lead to runaway inflation and the dollar's debasement.
Treasuries due in 10 or more years have returned 28 percent in 2011, exceeding the 24.4 percent gain in all of 2008 during worst financial crisis since the Great Depression, according to Bank of America Merrill Lynch indexes. Not since 1995, when the securities soared 30.7 percent, have investors done so well owning longer-dated U.S. government debt. 
Tell me why business people pay attention to the WSJ editorial page?

HEADLINE: Monday Motorsports: Win at Singapore Puts Sebastian Vettel Within One Point of Formula One Championship

BYLINE: JONATHAN SCHULTZ


HIGHLIGHT: The Red Bull racer's latest achievement made a back-to-back championship appear imminent. 

 BODY:
With floodlights illuminating a course that his Red Bull teammate Mark Webber called "probably the toughest of all for drivers," Sebastian Vettel continued his second-half resurgence, winning the Singapore Grand Prix on Sunday night. It was his third consecutive victory, having logged wins at Monza in Italy, Spa-Francorchamps in Belgium and the Hungaroring in Hungary, and his ninth over all in 2011.
Vettel, the pole sitter for Sunday's race, used his optimal track position to beat his competitors off the line and surged ahead to open as much as a 12-second gap between his car and that of Jenson Button, the McLaren-Mercedes driver, before the leaders made their first pit stops on lap No. 14. A drive-through penalty was levied against Lewis Hamilton, Button's teammate, after he clipped Felipe Massa, Ferrari's No. 2 driver. The penalty dropped Hamilton back as far as 15th, but he recovered to finish fifth.
Michael Schumacher, the seven-time Formula One champion, collided with the rear of Sergio Perez's Sauber car on lap No. 30, sending Schumacher's racer airborne. Neither driver was injured, but it caused a restart. Upon the restart, Button's progress was impeded by a number of backmarkers -- cars that could be lapped -- yet Button broke free and kept closing on Vettel, but finished more than a second behind. He was followed on the podium by Webber, who passed Ferrari's Fernando Alonso, who won the Singapore GP last year, in the waning laps.
As Brad Spurgeon at the Formula One blog notes, barring a catastrophe, Vettel's 2011 championship appears to be a foregone conclusion:
"Vettel has 124 points more than Button, with five races left and 25 points awarded for a victory. Vettel leads the series with 309 points to 185 for Button. He needs only one point to take the title, and that, of course, will be merely a formality for the German driver, 24."
In other motorsports news:
Tony Stewart, who only qualified for the Nascar Chase for the Sprint Cup in the final race of the regular season, secured his second victory of the series' de facto playoffs, winning handily at New Hampshire Motor Speedway on Sunday. Stewart passed Clint Bowyer with three laps remaining as Bowyer began to run out of fuel and maintained his lead to the finish. Stewart pressed his fuel advantage at Chicagoland on Sept. 19, as well. Frontrunners from the regular season, including Jimmie Johnson, Kyle Busch and Matt Kenseth, continue to struggle to find their chase footing.
 Last week, Group Lotus announced that Jean Alesi, who competed in Formula One from 1989 to 2001, as well as the DTM series in Germany and Le Mans in France, would drive in the 2012 Indianapolis 500. Alesi, 47, has acted as a brand ambassador for the group and its niche sports-car holding, Lotus Cars, since January, and has consulted on the development of the $1 million Exos Type 125 track-day racecar.
 The Detroit Grand Prix may run again at Belle Isle, according to a report by the Associated Press. The Detroit City Council approved an application submitted by organizers, including the Penske Corporation, the automotive retail and racing conglomerate, to lease the circuit for undisclosed competitions. The grand prix, which briefly returned in 2007 after a six-year hiatus, consisted of a weekend of IndyCar, American Le Mans and GT-class racing. It was canceled after its 2008 edition amid a weakening economy.

HEADLINE: Trump Meets With Romney in New York

BYLINE: ASHLEY PARKER


HIGHLIGHT: Mitt Romney will meet with the real estate mogul and television personality Donald Trump, following the example of other Republican candidates. 

 BODY:
3:05 p.m. | Updated Mitt Romney followed the well-trod path of other Republican presidential hopefuls on Monday with a trip to New York to kiss the ring of the real estate mogul and television personality Donald Trump.
The meeting between the two men, set up at Mr. Romney's request, took place at 2 p.m. Monday at Trump Towers on Fifth Avenue, and was the first time the two men chatted face-to-face since Mr. Romney declared his candidacy several months ago.
Mr. Romney managed to evade the press and neither man came out after the meeting to comment on what was discussed. But that obscured the fact that Mr. Trump, who flirted with a presidential run earlier this year and still likes to hint that he's keeping his options open, hasn't already had some things to say about Mr. Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts. 
In an interview in April with Meghan McCain, the daughter of Senator John McCain of Arizona, for The Daily Beast, Mr. Trump said that Mr. Romney was "going to lose."
"He doesn't resonate, you know, or he would have won last time, in all fairness to your father!" he told Ms. McCain. Mr. Trump said he watched Mr. Romney give a speech, "and it was all these little trivial statements."
The same month, he also bragged that he was a "much bigger businessman" than Mr. Romney.
"I mean, my net worth is many, many, many times Mitt Romney," Mr. Trump told CNN's Candy Crowley.
Mr. Romney has centered his campaign on jobs and the economy, promoting his years in the private sector, but Mr. Trump has also questioned whether Mr. Romney's time at Bain Capital actually helped create jobs.
"Well, Mitt Romney is a basically small-business guy, if you really think about it," Mr. Trump said in April. "He was a hedge fund. He was a funds guy. He walked away with some money from a very good company that he didn't create. He worked there. He didn't create it."
Despite Mr. Trump's less-than-laudatory comments, the Democratic National Committee released a Web video on Monday morning linking Mr. Romney and Mr. Trump.
"Both support an economic plan that would help out the richest and the big corporations, but not the middle class," says the narrator, who also says the two men would "slash Social Security" and "end Medicare as we know it."
The video ends with a montage of Mr. Trump offering up his trademark "You're fired" to the pair.
Mr. Trump has become a must-stop for Republican candidates seeking their party's 2012 nomination. Mr. Trump had dinner at the upscale Jean Georges restaurant in New York last week with Gov. Rick Perry of Texas, and he has a second meeting scheduled next week with Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota.
He also met withSarah Palin in May. The two went to the chain Famous Famiglia in Time Square, where they were roundly mocked for eating their pizza with knives and forks.

HEADLINE: Ford Mulling E.V.'s and Lincolns for China

BYLINE: PAUL STENQUIST


HIGHLIGHT: Alan R. Mulally, the automaker's chief executive, said that E.V.'s and the introduction of the Lincoln brand figured in Ford's China strategy. 

 BODY:
China does not lack for local manufacturers eager to collaborate with Western automakers, particularly in the development of electric vehicles. Alan R. Mulally threw Ford's hat in the ring on Saturday in an interview with Bloomberg Television, during which the chief executive gave indications that Ford may build E.V.'s there.
The automaker, which displayed its Focus Electric model at the Shanghai auto show in April, would follow General Motors and Daimler AG among major brands to announce their E.V. intent in China. Just last week, G.M. said it would develop E.V. architecture with S.A.I.C., its partner in China, at a jointly administered engineering center in Shanghai, while Daimler announced a joint venture with BYD in May of last year.
Ford, like its chief executive, is not talking specifics yet about an E.V. joint venture. Daniel Pierce, a Ford spokesman, related the following message from his colleagues in China when asked about the brand's E.V. plans:
"We have a fleet of electric demonstration vehicles in China, but have not announced any plans to sell or produce electric vehicles in China. If we decide to produce electric vehicles in China, we would then determine what technologies would be appropriate to share with our joint venture and also what terms would accompany such an arrangement."
According to China's Ministry of Science, the government hopes to have one million electric-powered vehicles on the road by 2015, which also happens to be aligned with the ambitions of the Obama administration for the United States. Mr. Mulally said that the introduction of electric vehicles in China would be dependent on the development of charging infrastructure and advances in battery technology.
To Bloomberg, Mr. Mulally said that Ford may also introduce the Lincoln brand in China, which has demonstrated demand for American luxury sedans. J.D. Power & Associates, the marketing information service, forecasts that China's luxury automobile market may grow by about 35 percent this year.
"We have a great luxury brand in Lincoln, which we have recommitted ourselves to," Mr. Mulally said in the television interview. "There's going to be tremendous pull from China to have access to these great vehicles."
Mr. Pierce, meanwhile, said that Ford has not announced plans to launch Lincoln in China.
While the automaker ponders its options in the world's largest automotive market, other Ford models, including the Transit Connect, Edge, Focus, Fiesta and the Mondeo and S-Max, two models unavailable in the United States, are being sold in China.
Ford has invested heavily in joint-venture engine, transmission and vehicle production plants in the country. In April at the Shanghai auto show, Joe Hinrichs, an executive for Ford Asia Pacific and Africa, said the brand would introduce 15 new vehicles in China by 2015. Announcing the appointment of David L. Schoch as chairman and chief executive of Ford Motor China, Mr. Hinrichs noted that the automaker had "put in place aggressive expansive plans" in the country.

HEADLINE: Delegating Economic Policy to the Technocrats, and Away from Democracy

BYLINE: CATHERINE RAMPELL


HIGHLIGHT: Peter Orszag suggests delegating more authority to "depoliticized" expert panels. But many economic decisions involve subjective value judgments, not sheer expertise. 

 BODY:
In a column in The New Republic, Peter Orzsag, President Obama's former budget director, argues for making the country's policy-setting less dysfunctional by making it "less democratic." One means for reducing politicized gridlock, he says, is to delegate more authority to "depoliticized commissions" of experts.
This is similar to the rationale behind establishing the Federal Reserve as an independent body: The Fed, at least theoretically, is shielded from short-term political interests. It can instead make decisions based what is good for the long-term interest of the economy, as determined by immutable economic laws and objective academic research. (In reality, of course, there have been many attempts to put political pressure on the Fed over the years, and within the central bank there is still broad disagreement about what's best for the long-term interest of the economy.)
Mr. Orszag also notes some other expert commissions, such as the military-base closing commissions, and the Independent Payment Advisory Board (IPAB), created by last year's Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act to make changes to the Medicare payment system. The military-base closing commissions have generally been effective, and the jury is still out on the nascent IPAB.
On narrowly defined (and often technical) policy issues, expert panels can be useful. But as I wrote in an article last year about politicians' poor incentives, delegating policy authority to technocratic panels is more problematic when dealing with larger economic matters that involve social value judgments, like austerity measures and tax reform.
These policy areas may sound like dry academic subjects. But they are thoroughly infused with, and ultimately shaped by, moral beliefs.
There are, after all, infinite combinations of spending cuts and tax increases that can add up to the same bottom line. Deciding what should get trimmed and what taxes should be increased or decreased involves questions of favoritism, welfare, compassion, fairness and all sorts of other subjective judgments not answerable by the "laws" of economics.
It's not clear that a doctorate in economics (or, for that matter, in theology) gives a person any more moral authority than anyone else. That's why such decisions are decided through a republican democracy -- both lower case -- and not by genius academics, however messy and dysfunctional the resulting process may be.

HEADLINE: Obama and 'Young Guns' Make Silicon Valley Pitches

BYLINE: JENNIFER PRESTON and SARAH WHEATON


HIGHLIGHT: President Obama and Republican leaders go further in using social media to get their messages across. 

 BODY:
8:15 p.m. | Updated Six miles from where President Obama held a Town Hall on Monday with LinkedIn's executives in Mountain View, Calif., to discuss his jobs plan, the House Republican leaders who describe themselves as "The Young Guns" gathered atFacebook's headquarters for a 6 p.m. ET live discussionon their vision of what needs to be done to jumpstart the economy.
It is the latest example of how President Obama - and Republican Congressional leaders - are using social media platforms to engage in discussions directly with people about their approaches to solve the nation's economic woes.
At Facebook, Sheryl Sandberg, the chief operating officer who worked as the chief of staff to former Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, led the discussion with Representative Eric Cantor of Virginia, the House Majority leader, Representative Paul Ryan of Wisconsin who is chairman of the budget committee and Representative Kevin McCarthy of California. They published a book last year called "Young Guns: A New Generation of Conservative Leaders."
Questions for the three House Republican leaders are posted here on this Facebook page. The live event from Facebook's headquarters, where Facebook employees will also pose questions, can be watched here.
By late afternoon, there were questions posted on the Facebook wall about the future of Social Security, the threat of a government shutdown and the debate over extending the Bush tax cuts to the wealthy. "What justifiable reason is there for the mega rich paying a lesser percentage of wages and earnings than the middle class?" wrote Linda Mussaw.
Earlier in the day, Mr. Obama appeared at the Computer History museum, where he answered questions curated by LinkedIn employees from thousands posted by people who belong to LinkedIn's network.
"The LinkedIn town hall was a great chance for the President to hear directly from LinkedIn members across the country, to answer their questions and to discuss with them how his jobs plan will impact the economy and put Americans back to work," a White House spokesman said.
Mr. Obama appeared with Ms. Sandberg and Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, for a similar Facebook live chat earlier this year.
As the House leaders spoke at the Facebook event, the Senatewas voting on yet another version of a stopgap spending bill in an effort to keep the government from shutting down over a dispute over disaster aid funding. Mr. Cantor was at the center of that dispute earlier this month, when he suggested that government should find savings equal to the extra money allocated to the Federal Emergency Management Agency.
But on Monday afternoon, Mr. Cantor said the spending debate is subject of "a lot of hyperbole in the press."
"I'm positive we'll get this thing done," he added.
The "Young Guns" held their fire at Democrats - perhaps aware of the youthful, left-coast audience, and instead focused on their own policy prescriptions, such as using social media like Facebook to better connect people to their government and reducing the government regulatory structure to encourage small businesses.
"It took more hours to go through Dodd-Frank than it did to build the Empire State Building," said Mr. McCarthy, using an analogy that might have been somewhat intangible to an audience that sees through lines of code rather than scaffolding.
The mainstream media were also a frequent target. The House Republicans criticized the conventional press for neglecting to cover certain stories and for separating officeholders from their constituents.
Electronic communication "strips away the intermediary between the people and their government," said Mr. Ryan, and Mr. McCarthy added, "I think it takes the spin out, too."
That attitude represents an approach the "Young Guns" share with Mr. Obama, whose administration has used almost every type of social media, from Flickr to Monday's LinkedIn event, to bypass the press.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Facebook Forms a PAC

BYLINE: MICHAEL D. SHEAR and JENNIFER PRESTON


HIGHLIGHT: In forming a political action committee, Facebook is joining other social media companies in efforts to integrate with the political landscape. 

 BODY:
Facebook wants more friends. And it's willing to pay for them.
The Silicon Valley social media company has for the first time formed an old-fashioned political action committee and will use it to distribute cash to candidates in the coming elections. It is just one indication of how social media companies are integrating with the political landscape in a season in which these businesses are growing presences in the campaign conversation.
"FB PAC will give our employees a way to make their voice heard in the political process by supporting candidates who share our goals of promoting the value of innovation to our economy while giving people the power to share and make the world more open and connected," a company spokesman said.
The move comes as technology companies like Facebook are moving quickly to increase their influence in Washington amid increasingly complex legislative debates about patents, monopoly status and concerns about the privacy of users.
And it reflects a new desire among the senior executives at Google, Facebook, LinkedIn and other companies to use their novel technologies to be part of the political process in ways that they haven't before.
Google co-sponsored a Republican presidential debate with Fox News last week. On Monday, Facebook held a town hall meeting featuring top House Republicans just hours after LinkedIn held a similar town hall with President Obama.

Executives at Facebook declined to offer more details about their political action committee or say which races it would make contributions to. The company confirmed the group was incorporated on Monday after it was reported that it had registered the Internet domains for FBPAC.org and FBPAC.us.
Facebook has steadily increased its presence in Washington as it has grown. In 2007 it hired its first employee in the District of Columbia, and the office now has more than a dozen, including four federally registered lobbyists. The amount they have spent lobbying Congress has grown as well.
"The increase represents a continuation of our efforts to explain how our service works as well as the important actions we take to protect people who use our service and promote the value of innovation to our economy," said Andrew Noyes, a Facebook spokesman.
The company's competitors are also increasing their presence in the nation's capital as the competition for market dominance increasingly turns to legislative and regulatory fights.
According to disclosure documents filed in July, both Facebook and Google spent more money on lobbyists in the second quarter than ever before in yet another sign that the two technology giants are concerned about getting attention in Washington. Google increased its spending on lobbyists to $2.06 million in the second quarter, up from $1.48 million in the first quarter.
Facebook's spending on lobbying, while significantly less, increased to $320,000 in the second quarter, up from $230,000 in the first, according to an analysis by the Center for Responsive Politics.
Google opened its Washington office in 2006, the same year it started its own political action committee. In that year, the company's committee distributed $36,984, according to OpenSecrets.Org, which tracks campaign spending. By 2010, the committee had distributed $345,000, all for congressional campaigns.
Google's office in Washington has grown as well. It now has 11 registered lobbyists as well as engineers, sales representatives and employees who work with enterprise clients, according to a company spokeswoman.
Last week, Eric Schmidt, the chairman of Google's board and the former chief executive, testified before a subcommittee of the Senate Judiciary Committee on the issue of competition.
Mr. Schmidt told the committee that Google is in "the area" of a monopoly but is engaged in fierce competition with other companies.
Like Google, Facebook is facing increasing questions from lawmakers about the impact of its practices on its customers.
In May of 2010, the founder of Facebook, Mark Zuckerberg, wrote an opinion article in The Washington Post to respond to charges that it had acted cavalierly with user data and had made it too complicated for people to protect their privacy.
"The biggest message we have heard recently is that people want easier control over their information," Mr. Zuckerberg wrote. "Simply put, many of you thought our controls were too complex."
Jamie Court, president of Consumer Watchdog, a nonpartisan group that focuses on privacy issues, said that it is not surprising that Facebook is looking to step up its lobbying efforts, particularly given new concerns about privacy issues since Facebook announced major changes to its platform last week.
"Facebook is monetizing its platform," Mr. Court said. "This is all about how much it is going to be able to push the envelope with consumers and not have the government require it to change."
Last week, when Mr. Schmidt was testifying before the Senate subcommittee, he was followed by three professional mimes who were working with the Consumer Watchdog group as part of an effort to show what it is like "to be tracked." The group supports legislation that would allow consumers to put themselves on a "do not track list" that would be similar to the "do not call list."
Mr. Court said having the mimes follow Mr. Schmidt in Washington was intended to demonstrate "how annoying it is to be tracked in the real world and not just online."
